everything-in-its-right-place.raw_content:
Free will is an error in the code. We're pushing a patch next week.

The man behind the counter grinned inside and told me I'd be fine. We share the same thoughts, he and I. We care for the same things. I hunger. I weep. I seek to end this loneliness. I'm Broken. I've always been Broken.

He removes my eyes. I see his lips up close. Smooth skin. Nothing out of place. Flesh is pulled taut over his form. There is a flicker as my sight shifts. He knows better than to show imperfections to his customers. My new eyes would notice. I can see in technicolor. A new world with blues so sharp they cut your bones. I want to be just as unique as everyone else. He turns my new eyes around to look at my face. I can see everything.

Puffy bloated cheeks. Greasy gray hair. Wrinkles where they ought not be. And every line stretches back to forever. A perfect path between yesterday and tomorrow with me providing the through-line. The man squishes my old eyes into jelly while I judge my own face and I grin inside.

The machine assistant grabs the corners of my lips and pulls the cheeks tight. A scalpel comes down, cutting where the lines meet my face. The flesh rips and tears away and I am nothing. Muscle and bone glistening until the duraskin mask comes down. It glows with fairy fire. I want to scream but I cannot find my voice.

There's a gallery here in the operating room. A hundred perfect faces smiling down at the operation of my life. The face burns itself into place where my old one lived. Seals the agony in. But we're only getting started. The wires come down from the ceiling. They plug into my ports. Under my arms. Behind my knees. The wires plug into my mind and I feel the electricity struggle against my thoughts. Chrome and bronze and gears and life come find me in my holes.

I'm dancing now. The wires in my brain are moving me. It is awkward at first. I don't know what I'm doing. I'm too imperfect to have danced before. So the wire plugged into my mind adapts. The experiences download. Now, I'm capable. My limbs move with purpose and grace. And the wires in my bones snake their way into my marrow. They replace the white with silver.

I cry. Small tears come first. Then I cry harder at how they see me. With their unmoved faces and hard eyes. Some of them climb down, spider-like, into the surgical theater. Something terrible is happening. It is happening to me. Lights. Sounds. Beeps. It is not normal. It is not right. They are wired too, I see. The wires follow their movements. No. The wires move them. Just as I am moved.

I'm not supposed to cry. I'm not supposed to feel. I thought they cut that out of me. But still I weep. There's no salt or water in the tear ducts anymore so silver flows down my newly perfect cheeks. It pools on the ground. The wires hang me. They dance me. They do not let me touch the ground. I cannot feel what is beneath me.

The helpers are hurried and concerned. But the man who took my money to make me perfect is unbothered. I no longer dance. I no longer care. The substrate is clean. All the hooks into my psyche have taken perfectly. My eyes are in their proper place. So is everything else.

The gallery applauds. I have been Unbroken. I have been made perfect. Unique. Like everyone else. I can show my face. I look up at them. I smile inside. My duraskin face does not move.

I bow.

The event that was my life is over. A new event begins.

I think that to pay back that control, to let him have my time and heart, is the sincerest reconciliation.

And if I think malignantly, if my heart
Reaches out and yearns to tear apart
The children of God

Please let him smite me down
Let my penance be known
The sin that I self-brought.

    Title: Fine, Then: An ArtEx2025 Gift for mxsinister
    Author: Wynths
    Word Count: 12845 Words

    Somewhat inspired by A Wonderful Saga of Twisted Entertainment and greatly inspired by 'dad', you're too fucking late

12845 words


19:30 at the Cheshire Cat Café. Look at the waiters bringing out big plates and hefty glasses, mostly occupied by decoration, rarely intended for use. Their tumbling suits cover half-buttoned dress shirts and undone cuffs. They approach silence on the glistening marble floor, patterned with black square accent and beige-granite diamonds. The expression on their faces maybe that of humility and discipline, a beyond from the typical politeness and polity that might have impressed gentlemen in a different age. Touch the seats, and run fingers across their fine surfaces, exposed and smooth, running warm despite either constant foot traffic or cloudless winter winds.
And the tables are good too: thick mahogany, un-laminated and stain free. Knock, and find it silenced by a thick packed core. In the kitchens, air comes out from the multitudinous platters and the rolling stovetop plains which attack hotly steak and chicken and other, fancy, in-house things; it wafts around in the air as the cooks rush around, and it goes into a whirl, and the whirl travels outwards towards the guests, who are pleasantly ambushed by that aromatic collusion. Breathe it. Gaze outwards towards the guests, the three outside of all this.

They are silhouettes, and they rage against mountainous made-mosaic skies, sunset doled out only this hour for the important clientele.

Redd brings with him a rough mesa overcoat — Carhartt, pressed and cleaned — and carpenter's jeans with paint scraped off and an unseemly boil of a hammer loop hacked off. He covertly handles a pocketknife in the left-hand pocket, flipping it in and out, pressing the edge against his leg. The tip of the blade gives a dull baseline of pain, and the folding of the knife, muted by weather and cloth, taps on his thigh like a BB pellet against steel. He bounces his leg as he takes his seat near the edge of the tall edifice, and he looks out to the cliff which the outdoor seating overhangs. He looks at the beauty.
Dr. Wondertainment removes a handkerchief inscribed with his signature from the left breast pocket of his amethyst suit, and he walks to the handrail, and examines the world. He takes a hold of it for a little while and sees it in his palm — the sinusoidal skyline of the great city stabbing on occasion into the domain of Luna, and the yellow and white of the soft interior lights overwhelming the buildings and giving them a sort of angelic glow. Against the distant vestiges of Gaia, one could believe that this Mosaic was simply another biome of existence, ready-made as it were,ⓘTales of the MosaicOur city is a picture of a thousand little worlds – a thousand little stories, each one truer than the last. springing out from the Earth and allowing its nubile, dangling limbs to reach out to the Heavens in distilled ambition, like inverted udders of Man. It would not be so wonderful in this place — the Doctor decides as he wipes the sweat off himself and lets his body relax from the long walk — if there were fossils of steel under those great foundations that must surely pave the streets, embryonic testaments to a past Man.
Isabel leans against the outer frame for a moment before exiting the Café. The whiplash of the humidity and dry about-50° of the balcony fight the fat furry coat and double-layered sweats/trousers that she dons. Her beanie is flimsy and makes her scalp colder for wearing it, something that she realizes only after stepping past the threshold and joining the disjointed family at the cold dinner table.

Elena brings them a bread basket, woven, thin enough to be skin, aroma of Monterrey on a special blend of herbs — recipe taken from a new cook. Water is coming: good, they say, and it is set to be fetched in a dozen minutes. Menus are opened and glanced.

"I want you to pick me a plate." Redd says after an uncomfortable warming period.

"Ah." Dr. Wondertainment nods and lets out a small smile, chiseling out an almost cherubic face, only a tone of control and nervous fatigue tainting the half-genuine facade. "Hmmm… I've got to say, the Gnocci soup was always a good favorite of mine-"

The Doctor looks at Redd, who himself turns to look inside at the massive kitchen, dozens of people scurrying around in indecipherable, purposeful patterns. "-Though if you've the appetite for something heavier, the roast lamb is fine."

Redd continued to look away. He tapped his fingers on the table, a basic rhythm that Isabel could almost place. "Roast lamb'll be fine."

There was a long silence in which the father and the son couldn't look in the same direction as each other. Redd was attracted to the short, wide chandeliers which functioned almost as skyholes rather than fixtures, while Wondertainment's gaze went to Isabel and her many layers, as though he were some sort of sailor, battered against an impossible challenge and leaning upon a stern gate. Now that Redd had apparently chosen to give him space, he did not bother to hide his downcastness.
After a minute of this, Redd shifted back to the table. He caught a glint of his father's dejection, and quickly grabbed a piece of bread. He spent a long time eating it, and the Doctor played with something in his suit before assuming what in another setting could have been a negotiatory pose. The winds grew a little more; Redd's hood fluttered a little, and Dr. Wondertainment's suit listed towards the restaurant. Elena returned, and her cheerful demeanor, though cracking from the lunatic idea of serving outdoors in these conditions, invigorated the three of them, as though they had finally been given permission to speak. The dam burst as she left, whispering their order so that it would live to see the terminal: Roas' lam', mash potato coleslaw si'e, L ice tea, no ice. Lemanade. 2 Noh-cee soup, 8 mozzy brea'sticks. Parmy san'which.

"So, Redd…" The Doctor began.

"Hm?"

"Have you… gone back to Myke and Snell's since you came here?" The Doctor rests his arm on the table and leans in.

"Oh, damn —" Redd tisks at himself. " — Honestly? I'd forgotten that place had even fucking existed." He slides back a little and leans backwards, cracking his back in a habitual way. "It, uh, has been a long time. I know that."

"It was shuttered."

"Really?" Redd squints for a moment.

"Not enough clientele. They did keep the offices open, however." The Doctor inhales deeply, taking some of the cold into his body. "And…" He trailed off, then continued, knowing that he had forced his own hand, and was liable to say something treacherous. "I've been going back there."

Isabel chimed in now, glancing at Redd to ensure that she wasn't being explicitly rude. "He's done it some ten or twelve times. Just goes out every summer and waits for you." She slid just a little to Redd, hoping to make it clear that she desired to be neutral, somehow.

"And the hell would you do that for?" Redd said quickly.

"I." And the Doctor stopped. Isabel looked up from her notepad to find the Doctor at an impasse of words. It was astonishing. He looked at her, then at his son. Redd smirked.

Dr. Wondertainment is like an old, unstable chimney: his voice wobbles in the wind; his chest shakes slightly, tectonically; he is grim, as though he wears sackcloth underneath the suit.

The Doctor smirks and shakes his head. "The greatest that ever lived."

Redd begins. "Hey, uhm…, uh-"

The Doctor says, "What is it?"

"Can I get you Sirs and the Madame anything?" Elena says

The food is good and plenty. It hardly fits onto the table, so Elena brings them a pop-stand and places the VSOP, snifters, and extra bowl of soup there. "I don't know."

"Hmm…"

"He brought someone with him too."

"Who?"

"Isabel. He says that she is partially a child. Adopted, you could say."

"Does she convince you?"

"Maybe. I think she wasn't herself. Too much going on, her world god damned shattered."

"Poor Isabel, being put into that mess with no warning."

"Hm, I wouldn't say poor. I just don't think she understands forgiveness, really."

"Why would you say that?"

"I don't think she's ever had to forgive. Or ever forgiven someone."

"Still, poor girl."

"Why's that?"

"She must've never lived."

"Oh, that's nonsense… she's part of Wondertainment, that's why her life has been great thus far."

"Maybe her life hasn't been. And she still hasn't seen that yet."

"Good point… very good point."

"Oh, a last thing."

"Hm?"

"Do you still think the Doctor is good?"

"Yes. I… want to meet him again, if that's what you say."

"Will you come to bed with me?"

"Of course."

"…I'm proud of you, Redd."

"And I love you, Nata."

"Wait, before we go..?"

"Hm?"

"Will you bring the Doctor and Isabel for Christmas?"

"Of course… if they want."

"They'll come."

"I hope."

"I love you, Redd."

"I love you, Nata."

Merry Christmas!
fine-then.raw_source: ===== [[include component:preview text=I think that to pay back that control, to let him have my time and heart, is the sincerest reconciliation.]] ===== [[include :scp-wiki:component:hoverlinks]] [[include :scp-wiki:theme:black-highlighter-theme]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:betterfootnotes]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:centered-header-bhl]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:toggle-sidebar-bhl]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:fade-in speed=3]] [[include :scp-wiki:theme:xmas |xmas-snow-bhl= --] |xmas-header-bhl= --]]] [[=]] //And if I think malignantly, if my heart// //Reaches out and yearns to tear apart// //The children of God// //Please let him smite me down// //Let my penance be known// //The sin that I self-brought.// [[/=]] [[include :scp-wiki:info:start]] **Title:** Fine, Then: An ArtEx2025 Gift for [[*user mxsinister]] **Author:** [[*user Wynths]] **Word Count: 12845 Words** Somewhat inspired by [*https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/twistedgears-personnel-file A Wonderful Saga of Twisted Entertainment] and greatly inspired by [*https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/to-my-companion-who-sleeps-eternally-beyond-reach 'dad', you're too fucking late] [[include :scp-wiki:info:end]] [[include :scp-wiki:component:ratio-bar base=-- |ex=--]] [[>]] [[size 75%]]//12845 words//[[/size]] [[/>]] [[span style="float:left;color:#ffffff;font-size:80px;line-height:70px;padding-top:5px;padding-right:8px;font-family: times, georgia;padding-left:5px;background:#990011;margin-right:10px"]]1[[/span]]9:30 at the Cheshire Cat Café. Look at the waiters bringing out big plates and hefty glasses, mostly occupied by decoration, rarely intended for use. Their tumbling suits cover half-buttoned dress shirts and undone cuffs. They approach silence on the glistening marble floor, patterned with black square accent and beige-granite diamonds. The expression on their faces maybe that of humility and discipline, a beyond from the typical politeness and polity that might have impressed gentlemen in a different age. Touch the seats, and run fingers across their fine surfaces, exposed and smooth, running warm despite either constant foot traffic or cloudless winter winds. And the tables are good too: thick mahogany, un-laminated and stain free. Knock, and find it silenced by a thick packed core. In the kitchens, air comes out from the multitudinous platters and the rolling stovetop plains which attack hotly steak and chicken and other, fancy, in-house things; it wafts around in the air as the cooks rush around, and it goes into a whirl, and the whirl travels outwards towards the guests, who are pleasantly ambushed by that aromatic collusion. Breathe it. Gaze outwards towards the guests, the three outside of all this. They are silhouettes, and they rage against mountainous made-mosaic skies, sunset doled out only this hour for the //important// clientele. Redd brings with him a rough mesa overcoat -- Carhartt, pressed and cleaned -- and carpenter's jeans with paint scraped off and an unseemly boil of a hammer loop hacked off. He covertly handles a pocketknife in the left-hand pocket, flipping it in and out, pressing the edge against his leg. The tip of the blade gives a dull baseline of pain, and the folding of the knife, muted by weather and cloth, taps on his thigh like a BB pellet against steel. He bounces his leg as he takes his seat near the edge of the tall edifice, and he looks out to the cliff which the outdoor seating overhangs. He looks at the beauty. Dr. Wondertainment removes a handkerchief inscribed with his signature from the left breast pocket of his amethyst suit, and he walks to the handrail, and examines the world. He takes a hold of it for a little while and sees it in his palm -- the sinusoidal skyline of the great city stabbing on occasion into the domain of Luna, and the yellow and white of the soft interior lights overwhelming the buildings and giving them a sort of angelic glow. Against the distant vestiges of Gaia, one could believe that [[span class="hoverlink"]][[[https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/tales-of-the-mosaic|this Mosaic was simply another biome of existence, ready-made as it were,]]]^^ⓘ^^[[span class="hoverlink-card"]][[span class="hoverlink-title"]]Tales of the Mosaic[[/span]][[span class="hoverlink-text"]]Our city is a picture of a thousand little worlds – a thousand little stories, each one truer than the last.[[/span]][[/span]][[/span]] springing out from the Earth and allowing its nubile, dangling limbs to reach out to the Heavens in distilled ambition, like inverted udders of Man. It would not be so wonderful in this place -- the Doctor decides as he wipes the sweat off himself and lets his body relax from the long walk -- if there were fossils of steel under those great foundations that must surely pave the streets, embryonic testaments to a past Man. Isabel leans against the outer frame for a moment before exiting the Café. The whiplash of the humidity and dry about-50° of the balcony fight the fat furry coat and double-layered sweats/trousers that she dons. Her beanie is flimsy and makes her scalp colder for wearing it, something that she realizes only after stepping past the threshold and joining the disjointed family at the cold dinner table. ---- Elena brings them a bread basket, woven, thin enough to be skin, aroma of Monterrey on a special blend of herbs -- recipe taken from a new cook. Water is coming: good, they say, and it is set to be fetched in a dozen minutes. Menus are opened and glanced. "I want you to pick me a plate." Redd says after an uncomfortable warming period. "Ah." Dr. Wondertainment nods and lets out a small smile, chiseling out an almost cherubic face, only a tone of control and nervous fatigue tainting the half-genuine facade. "Hmmm... I've got to say, the Gnocci soup was always a good favorite of mine-" The Doctor looks at Redd, who himself turns to look inside at the massive kitchen, dozens of people scurrying around in indecipherable, purposeful patterns. "-Though if you've the appetite for something heavier, the roast lamb is fine." Redd continued to look away. He tapped his fingers on the table, a basic rhythm that Isabel could //almost// place. "Roast lamb'll be fine." There was a long silence in which the father and the son couldn't look in the same direction as each other. Redd was attracted to the short, wide chandeliers which functioned almost as skyholes rather than fixtures, while Wondertainment's gaze went to Isabel and her many layers, as though he were some sort of sailor, battered against an impossible challenge and leaning upon a stern gate. Now that Redd had apparently chosen to give him space, he did not bother to hide his downcastness. After a minute of this, Redd shifted back to the table. He caught a glint of his father's dejection, and quickly grabbed a piece of bread. He spent a long time eating it, and the Doctor played with something in his suit before assuming what in another setting could have been a negotiatory pose. The winds grew a little more; Redd's hood fluttered a little, and Dr. Wondertainment's suit listed towards the restaurant. Elena returned, and her cheerful demeanor, though cracking from the lunatic idea of serving outdoors in __these__ conditions, invigorated the three of them, as though they had finally been given permission to speak. The dam burst as she left, whispering their order so that it would live to see the terminal: //Roas' lam', mash potato coleslaw si'e, L ice tea, no ice. Lemanade. 2 Noh-cee soup, 8 mozzy brea'sticks. Parmy san'which.// ----- "So, Redd..." The Doctor began. "Hm?" "Have you... gone back to Myke and Snell's since you came here?" The Doctor rests his arm on the table and leans in. "Oh, damn --" Redd tisks at himself. " -- Honestly? I'd forgotten that place had even fucking existed." He slides back a little and leans backwards, cracking his back in a habitual way. "It, uh, has been a long time. I know that." "It was shuttered." "Really?" Redd squints for a moment. "Not enough clientele. They __did__ keep the offices open, however." The Doctor inhales deeply, taking some of the cold into his body. "And..." He trailed off, then continued, knowing that he had forced his own hand, and was liable to say something treacherous. "I've been going back there." Isabel chimed in now, glancing at Redd to ensure that she wasn't being explicitly rude. "He's done it some ten or twelve times. Just goes out every summer and waits for you." She slid just a little to Redd, hoping to make it clear that she **desired** to be neutral, somehow. "And the hell would you do that for?" Redd said quickly. "I." And the Doctor stopped. Isabel looked up from her notepad to find the Doctor at an impasse of words. It was astonishing. He looked at her, then at his son. Redd smirked. "I -- [[span class="hoverlink"]][[[https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/to-my-companion-who-sleeps-eternally-beyond-reach|was writing letters. Apologies.]]]^^ⓘ^^[[span class="hoverlink-card"]][[span class="hoverlink-title"]]'dad', you're too fucking late[[/span]][[span class="hoverlink-text"]]Maybe someday he 'ought to bring them, show his son that he really did think of him, really did try in his own way.[[/span]][[/span]][[/span]]" The Doctor inspects the wood grain of the table. It is an oak-like pattern, with spiral coffee swirls against a dark chocolate backing. Scanning it gives him a will to continue. "I admit now, I did it more for myself than for you -- or else I might have been able to will myself to find you sooner." "Maybe." "What do you mean by that, Redd?" "Oh -- I, ah." Redd scratches the back of his head for a moment before continuing. "I mean that..." Redd stops for an instant as the Doctor looks at his son, wondering. Redd treads the next sentence carefully while realizing, in his heart of hearts, that the whole night would contain such wordplay. "I mean that, sometimes, people doing things just for themselves still helps others. Do you know what I mean by that?" The Doctor chuckles and returns to the wood grain. It was an allodynic thing, hearing Redd speak at length again. It was an evisceration of self-doubt -- doubt that the self could have been wrong -- to know that all the words of the previous night were totally measured and true when applied to himself. "Perhaps." "Fine, then. So, you-" Catching a glimpse of motion, Redd turns to look to the restaurant. Elena had returned with the glass of lemonade, a pitcher iced tea with no ice, an empty glass, and a bottle of Old Pale. "Oh, uhm, sorry, but we didn't --" Isabel began. "My manager says that it's compliments for the gentleman in velvet." Elena says. She meets Dr. Wondertainment's gaze as she places down the drinks, and smiles meekly. "Would you like anything else, Sir?" "Nothing, dear." The Doctor responds, giving a smile in kind. Elena goes. Redd seizes the gateway into his father and clamps down on the through-line with a hesitant "What's that about?" "The favor?" The Doctor has a hint of surprise in his voice, which makes Redd's cheeks go red and hot -- had he asked something that was Too Much? "Yeah." Redd says cautiously. The Doctor coughs into his suit sleeve and rubs his eyes. "It -- and this is a long story, now that I think of it, so I will be-" "You can take your time. We'll be here long as we need to, Natasha's got her." "Is that so?" Dr. Wondertainment and Isabel both look at each other, gauging the other -- the Doctor was curious, Isabel was obviously surprised. Thankfully, the incourtesy went unremarked upon. "Yes; I know I had said that I wouldn't leave my girl alone more than an hour, not with a babysitter, but my wife said she was able to call off work right after y'all left." Redd sighs. He says the rest of his thought quickly. "I bitched at her of course -- didn't want her to take out hours if she didn't need to, 'cuz she does //like// the work she does... but. You know." "I understand." The Doctor nods. "So, yeah." Redd says. The silence is tumultuous to Isabel, and she decides to attempt to keep them from it. "Doctor?" "Yes?" "What //was// that favor, the one that Elena mentioned?" The Doctor jolts up in his seat. "My goodness, I'd almost forgotten to explain it!" He turns to face Redd, "I'm sorry, if you were-" "It's fine, it's fine -- I was just a lil' curious, wasn't dying to know or anything." The Doctor looks to the restaurant, apparently searching. "I'll let you know simply, then -- I used to be good friends with the owner of this place, one 'Ira Wildecliffe', after I designed a special toy for his son. I was not remotely as experienced as I am now then, so the glasses -- " The Doctor snickers, Redd interjects. "Wait, wait... you say '//Ira// Wildecliffe'?" "Yes?" Redd takes a piece of bread, which held its heat despite the wind, and chews it quickly. He sips from his tea. "I just found that strange, because I actually __know__ a Wildecliffe. Boris Wildecliffe." "Ah, good to know!" The Doctor gives an honest, warm smile -- the type of thing that a grandparent would give their kid's kids, not knowing them well but loving them all the same... it was deeply strange to see on the man. Redd shook that train of thought away. "Why's that?" He asks. The Doctor puts a finger up. "I'm about to tell you: My glasses, which I had given the name of the Super Secret Spy Spectacles© to, were a little... odd. I had had issues with them regarding their blinding the user when I examined them, and I //believed// I had solved the problem when I had gifted them at last. The Doctor pushes his seat to the edge of the table and continues, closer than ever. "You see, the Spectacles© worked by altering the vision of the wearer, but if the wearer's spirit could not process the change, it simply resulted in the complete removal of it. But, I had applied a simple fix -- " The Doctor looks at Redd. He strokes his stubble and leans his elbow on the table. " -- And that was to simply give the brain the option to view heat signatures, and hope that the connection between the glasses and said ability would hold strong. Redd smirks. "And it didn't." "It did not, for the child that I had given it to was... perhaps bratty is a mean word, but no other occurs to me at this moment -- self-willed-" The Doctor begins to blush somewhat at the foul language that he has been forced into using. "-I think bratty'll be appropriate if even //you// want to call the little shithead that." Redd and the Doctor both laugh at that; thank goodness, Isabel thinks. The Doctor leans back in after a minute, "So then, let us call him bratty. And I say him, because his name was Boris." "No!" "Boris Wildecliffe, yes!" The Doctor seems to wrinkle with the emphasis. "And the Spectacles© I gifted him? He found them unnecessary, for he had __overheard__ a conversation I had with one of my assistants, and he knew the trick behind the Spectacles©." Redd shakes his head and closes his eyes. "Shhhh-eesh! Must've been hard to deal with that, I figure." He says in a strangely colloquial tone... Isabel thinks now that it was the type one would use with a coworker or close acquaintance. Perhaps it didn't mean anything, but she files it in the back of her mind for later thought. The Doctor goes on. "Oh, undoubtedly. In the end, though, I really appreciated his willingness to avoid using the ability I had granted him for ill purposes, and as I would periodically dine with him and his father, Boris began to consider himself a friend of mine." "Consider himself, you say?" "Well... I can't say at that time, of course, that we were friends -- he was a child -- but I did appreciate his company, and remember, at this time I still had the capacity to talk to every child to whom I had gifted a Wonder. And I'm sure __you__ know, Redd, how much I did this while it was feasible to do so!" Redd's lips wobble, and he looks away from the Doctor for a moment, focusing on something in the middle distance -- Isabel follows his gaze... it's probably a tree. Large one, pink, with the tones of Spring at an ungodly time of year. "Yeah, I remember." The Doctor winces. "Ah." Redd refocuses and assumes an assuring smile. "Nah, it's fine, I just ain't remember that, was all. 'Ma try and put it in the past, you know?" He says it delicately, in a paternal tone, emphasizing the 'You know' which, to Isabel's ears, is beginning to sound less like a tick and more like a choice. "I know." "Good. So, that's all well — you gave our guy Boris here the ability to have some heat X-ray's. Explains why he always fucked with us on the job site." Redd's smile deepens, and he looks behind himself, out to the back-offices of the Café, as though the words should have been swiftly punished. "What do you mean by that?" "Woul' whine and moan over anyone working carefully if they were on a scaffold." Redd tisks at an imaginary Boris, rubbing his temple exasperatedly. "Really pissed me off, 'cuz the scaffolds he did give us were //really// bad, really nervewracking -- I'ma be honest there -- but I ain't say anything."  "'Cuz, of course, it can get worse." The Doctor squints and nods. "Ah. I see." Isabel finds it very amusing to watch him slowly maneuver his notebook out of his side trouser's pocket, scribbling a few words down as Redd continues. "Hey, for what it's worth, the //fuckhead// hasn't done anything to me in... like, ten years now? I haven't worked for a company in a real long time." "I suppose that's a good thing, yes?" Redd sighs. "Uhhh...." He is silent for a while. Isabel notices that there are no cars in the city at this hour... without the din of engine fire, the world is terrifying. "Neutral, prob'ly." "How so?" Redd thinks for a moment. He scratches an itch on his arm, then speaks slowly, as though printing out words of permanent wisdom. "You can take as few hours as you want, but you can also take as many. Ain't no one telling you what to do, hard to find that balance." The Doctor nods so quickly that Isabel cannot help but believe him. "I can understand." Redd looks away from the Doctor, and whispers, "A little bit, yeah." The Doctor looks directly at Redd. "What do you mean by that?" He looks away as Redd finds his father's face again. "Do you refer to my assistants?" "A'course! Not everyone that works by themself gon' have a whole team of people. It's me and my lonesome, couple of guys I call to help and cowork if a job gets real hard. And maybe Natasha if shit gets to the wire." "Do you prefer it that way?" The Doctor raises his eyebrows, drinking in the answer that his son will give. "Hmph." Redd scratches at his nose, then coughs forcefully, reaching for a napkin and coughing into it. Redd throws the tissue towards the nearest trash bin, about 50 feet away, and Isabel watches in astonishment as he looks away before even seeing it enter the bin. Redd sips from his tea. The Doctor remains stoic, almost unsensible "Maybe. Nah, prob'ly." "That's fine then... I just worry a bit, that's all." The Doctor says. "That's funny." Redd says, running his hand through his hair. "Why's th-" The Doctor says. "-When the hell did you begin worrying?" ---- "What?" The question seems to send the Doctor reeling. Isabel flicks her head to look at him, herself anxious with the direction of the conversation. "When, pray tell, did you get it in your heart to come out here and worry about me?" Redd speaks quickly now, wanting to get in his word before some nebulous threat removes his right of speech. "I figure we was getting a little distracted, might return to the... //heart// a'the matter." The world appears still for a long moment. It also feels as though it contracts -- the inner cogs working to dilate it down to the Café, to the mouths and ears and pounding brains of the long-loitering trio. The Doctor gathers himself, taking in a good breath and grabbing at his left wrist. "About a week ago. I... uhm." "The Doctor's getting older, Redd." Isabel interjects -- she //did not// want to see the Doctor explain what he had in the hotel room, the night that they came to the city. It would have been too much for the old man, surely: one's heart could only take so much in a restless night before it simply gave out. "Do you want me to tell him, or do you think you can do it?" The Doctor grimaced. "Isabel, I'll be __**damned**__ if I can't so much as be sincere with my son." Redd loses the edge to his voice, and in its place, a whisper that is barely over the dying winds finds its way to his father, to the wrinkled, frail, //old// man before him. "Jesus, what's going on?" "I'm sorry... sorry, I just... agitated myself." Dr. Wondertainment said. He wiped his mouth with a handkerchief, despite having done so about a minute prior, and spoke. "About a month ago, I began to get these spots on my skin. It was a week ago when I realized what they meant." Redd narrows his eyes. "You got fucking cancer?" Isabel chimes in: "Something similar to it." The Doctor frowns as he speaks. "Look, what I want to say is: I will not die from this, alright? I can heal myself with the right dose of medicine and the right outlook on life. But it's... it's a reminder, no?" Redd nods, his lips wobbling. He taps his fingers rapidly on the table. "I see." "I should have come down sooner. I should have __tried__ sooner." Redd suddenly perks his head up. He looks at Isabel, who had dared to take a bite from her enormous sandwich. "Isabel, did you have anything to do with this?" She nods and chews quickly. "No -- and I put it on my life. The Doctor is..." Redd interrupts. "Hm." He scratches his neck. "I'll trust you on that." The Doctor says, "Well, I know I should have come sooner... but, I'm here now." He taps his fingers on the table, unsure of how to phrase the next sentence, until it comes together, fused from a million disparate thoughts which all beg for further questioning, an excuse to go out and be considered by the son. "I would like to know more about you, Redd. I want to get to know my lost son. I'm -- well, I'm sure you may not feel that I am sincere, I __promise__ I am --" Redd sighs for a long time. He puts his fork down. "What do you even want to know? That I'm fine, despite what you did? That I cobbled together a decent life in this city?" "I.." Dr. Wondertainment begins, then speeds up. "I want to catch up on seven years' news. I want to know how you've calmed down, I want to know how you met your wife, I want to know all the cute moments you've had with your daughter -- and, my goodness, I don't even know her __name__, still --" "Hey, hey." Redd puts a hand up. "What is the issue? Have I done something wrong?" The Doctor says. Redd puts his hand down. "Fuck. I mean, not right now, no..." Redd sighs. "Look, I get you're excited. I really do. But I don't want you to just... like, what do you even what to do?" He puts a finger up,  "Besides come here and have dinner and then go back to running Wondertainment." "Do you believe I have come here __merely__ to have an hour-long chat with you? After all of this time?" "I... figured you'd be the type." Redd glances away, then goes on, throwing air quotes to emphasize his now-proven-wrong thought. "Busy guy, has to manage teams and subteams and departments and PR and whatever." "No. I won't go." "Good. We've hardly even started, it feels like." "No. I mean I'm not going back." "Doctor, you can't be-" Isabel immediately jumps in. Redd sees that Isabel was obviously not briefed on this, she damn near chokes on her drink, slamming it down on the table like a judge's gavel. He talks with her. "Wait, are you serious? I-" "I have decided I want to retire. If I phrase that way, is it more palatable? Is it better understood?" It's unbelievable -- Doctor Wondertainment has something like irritation written on his face.  "Dad, you don't have to do this." Isabel opened her mouth but did not speak. Dr. Wondertainment is like an old, unstable chimney: his voice wobbles in the wind; his chest shakes slightly, tectonically; he is grim, as though he wears sackcloth underneath the suit. "Redd... I, need to get to... to, know you. I want you to not hate me." His was the face of the damned. "Before I die, I would like to know that. That's why I want to stay with you." "Again, you don't need to do that. God knows it'd be shittier if I knew you were only doing it because I thought you wanted to please me." Redd looks down. "I've been thinking of retiring, in any case. I've gotten older, and the illness I showed you is..." "A reminder?" "That is the best way to put it. A reminder." Redd smirked ."Old man, you're still easily going to outlive me. You know that damn well." "It won't be in the same way though. Or, at least, I am scared that I would not be in good health during the back half of my life." Redd scrunches his face again. "You sayin' you wanna put yourself down?" "No!" The Doctor smiled at Redd. "You haven't changed, have you? You're still a crude jokester at heart!" "A funny one too." The Doctor smirks and shakes his head. "The greatest that ever lived." There was a silence for a moment. Redd begins. "Hey, uhm..., uh-" The Doctor says, "What is it?" "Do you think Isabel... like-" Redd flusters himself, wondering how best to ask the question that has been bothering him. Isabel jumps in. "If you want me excused, I'll excuse myself." Redd rebuts her. "No! I'm fine talking in front of you, I was //actually// gon' say: Did the old man ever tell you about how we separated, anyways? I figure you should know that, if you really know nothing." Isabel made a pledging motion "I know nothing." "Good, good -- I figure we fill her in, no?" "Yes, we can tell Isabel." The Doctor stretches in his seat. Isabel notices they are the same stretches the Doctor does prior to entering a Wondertainment Co. board meeting. "So... when was this; got to be, like-" Redd says, and then stops. Elena walks towards them, apparently making the rounds, and it is her presence that lets them know that another couple of people have made their home near the far corner of the balcony, completely over the cliff, held by nothing but man's manufacturing. Perhaps it was worth it for the view, Redd thinks. "Can I get you Sirs and the Madame anything?" Elena says "No, it's fine Elena, you don't need to check on us any time soon." She turns. Redd gives as an afterthought: "We'll come back in and pay the tab and we're ready, thank you for asking." ---- "Alright, so, I was gon' say: this is like, 2002, yes?" Redd looks at the Doctor, who nods. "2002. And, the Foundation, you know, they're doing their thing -- this was a little before he made you, but he'd come up with the Little Misters idea, and he'd gotten a few out, me included. So I'm young, is what I'm saying." "And then, one day, Foundation decides that they wanna take some items from one of the warehouses we've got: over what, who the hell knows, I sure don't-" The Doctor interjects, "I remember this! It was over a product I had developed but hadn't marketed or shipped out -- the Awesome Adventurer's Grill© was the placeholder name." "Yeah, that fucking thing -- set kids on fire and roasted //them// instead of the meat, or something like that, it's been a while." The Doctor's meek smile freezes for a moment before going as normal. "It was a less grave flaw, but the general idea was the same." "General idea, yeah." Redd chuckles. "So, they took up //everything// that was in that safehouse, and that included young me, all fresh and 20 and buzzcut." Redd gulps his tea. "And, you know, I had no idea how to ##red|channel my redness##, so I'm running away from the armored up men like '//Who the hell are you, get the hell away from me!//' and scaring them cuz I'm laying down fire and shit without even realizin'!" Redd takes another gulp of his tea. "So, yeah, that whole debacle goes down, and despite all my best efforts, I ain't old enough to really understand how to fight back, so they bag and tag me and I'm put away somewhere... let's say, like, -84 or something -- no idea." "It was Site-84, I remember it clearly." "Thanks. So, the whole time I'm there -- which ain't that long, thankfully, because I get traded out very quickly once Wondertainment Co. starts bringing down shit and fury on that tiny little site -- I'm thinking to myself '//Who are these people?//, and I'm trusting that my Creator -- cuz I think of the Doctor, my dad, as the Creator right now -- is gonna be able to let me know something, let me figure this shit out." Redd hums for a moment, thinking, then says "You let her know the rest, you know what happened on the back-end better than I do." "For a proper contextualization... hm." The Doctor pauses here as well -- it was a difficult time, and hard to summarize in a way that, he felt, assigned an appropriate amount of blame. "I was, at this time, worried that the Foundation would attempt to incarcerate me, for various reasons. It was a bout of paranoia which I allowed to develop within myself, for I believed that it was merely worry, merely an encouragement of __precautionary__ behaviors. The Doctor turns around in his seat, taking in as much of the new inside as possible. "I just. Uhm." Redd goes to stare at his father as the Doctor turns around to see him again. "I wanted you to know that it was not your fault that..." He stops as Redd laughs. It grows out of a chuckle, sad and self contained, and rapidly, a furious prosody swells into it, until Redd opens his eyes as he laughs, and they are wide, piercing through Dr. Wondertainment and the high-backed restaurant seat and the ceramic-cement floor tile and the concrete foundation and the hard, packed soil -- through all of this, down to the scarlet layers of the inner Earth. And he does it until the Doctor feels a very foreign emotion, but one which has, nonetheless, invaded his life and planted its roots firmly in his heart over the course of the past week: dread. Isabel eventually falters in her promise of minimal-interference and walks to Redd, placing a hand on his shoulder. He stops, catching gulps of air between locked teeth. "I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I just heard you -- " Redd loses the sentence as his chest begins to bounce again, though he clearly does not want to laugh anymore. The Doctor locks eyes with his son and decides to press on. "What is it that catches your attention, Redd?" "The fact that //you// fucking say you're sorry." Isabel stiffens, her force momentarily clouded in a flash of rage -- __how dare he insult the Doctor, after all this supposed soul-searching and story-telling!__ The Doctor bolts to look at her, and it is his pleading expression that keeps Isabel from performing an act of pure Magic at that instant. Redd gives up after another few seconds, sighing raggedly. "It's a force of habit, alright? I'm sorry, really, it's a... //price// I pay sometimes for ##red|my scarlet past##... I'm sure you understand." He says. "I understand." The Doctor says. He then holds up a finger before Redd can snap to the next thing on his mind. "But you did mean it, didn't you?" "Mean what?" Redd says. The Doctor looks at him for a moment longer than he should have. "The... statement, that you don't think what I've said here was sincere. Was my really trying to connect with you again." Redd's posture changes -- shoulders slump, back relaxes, and feet cease tapping. "Look." Redd waits a moment, and then sighs softly. "How the hell am I supposed to believe sometimes that you have my best interests in mind, Dad, when it is clear that, someway or another, you //forget// about me while I was here. That //you// thought" Redd points at the Doctor's chest, "in your heart of hearts that I would remain an unchanged, damaged child who would cling to the protector as soon as he came back from what feels like a seven year smoke break -- seven-year smoke break, that, by the way, has been ninety-nine //point fucking nine// percent of my life." The Doctor remains silent. Isabel does not. "You've now mentioned that three times in this dinner //alone.//" Redd turns to look at her, unbelieving. She continues, unaware. "How are you supposed to change, genuinely, if you believe that no matter what **my** dad -- because I view Doctor Wondertainment as my true father --  it will never be good for you? That the apology you receive has to be perfect to be accepted. Do you understand how lucky it is -- " Isabel stops, a quick breathing stop for the pedagogically new, " -- that //you// receive any sort of apology whatsoever? That you have even the potential for closure, but choose, it seems, to God damned squander it?" Redd's fist becomes tenser as Isabel speaks. He would nearly have responded with fists, were it not for the years he had lived and the presence of the Doctor. "Isabel." "Yes, Doctor?" "I want you to leave me and Redd alone." The Doctor begins. "I understand that you may be angry by some parts that seem repetitive, that seem //out of order//, bu-" "I am not **against** anything!" Isabel throws her hands up in utter resignation. "I just want to ensure that this isn't some..." She feels eyes bore into her, but refuses to look up at the two of them. She soon finds the words. "...Some form of self-**flagellation.**" Redd opens his mouth, clearly agitated by her outsider view, but she goes on: "All you two have done for the past hour, it feels like, is go back and forth on who carries the most blame and tell small-talk tales between-" She takes a sharp breath, an injection right into the lungs that wouldn't be out of place were she drowning. "-**actually useful** interludes of conversation. I'm sorry, but it's **maddening** to see!" She shakes, wanting to let out more words... and she cannot. She sighs, looking at them both. They both appear interested. She takes a minute, and eventually, a few more words rise to the sea's surface, allowing themselves to be her buoy. "I want this to be **helpful** for the both of you, and I don't see how this has helped, selfish it might be to say that." She says. Dr. Wondertainment speaks first. "Isabel, look at me?" She does. The Doctor slides out of his seat and stands, motioning for her to do the same. Redd looks at the two of them, refusing to give even an ounce of emotion to the whole display. The Doctor lays a hand on Isabel's shoulder, standing slightly shorter than her, looking up at her face. She squirms, steeling herself for some private rebuke or public admonishment. "I __know__ that this level of patience appears __ridiculous__ to you; it is what I have prepared for. Just as Redd, I'm sure, was preparing for this moment, to the point where he did not try to kill me." He ends the sentence with a soft smile, a fact which incenses Isabel. Still, she listens. "That is why I have spent this time flowing about, simply speaking as Redd pleases. The way I see it, I have controlled him with my practical silence for __far, far__ longer than he is now with his-" The Doctor pauses. "-...__Swearing__ and vulgarity." The Doctor steps away from her, and speaks a little louder, enough so that Redd does not need to strain to eavesdrop. "I think, and perhaps you believe differently, that such control, to pay it back after having stolen it for so long, is the meaning of the word __reconciliation.__"   "I..." Isabel says after a silent moment, running her hand across the cold plastic and plating of the new Café's walls. The Doctor sits back down on the seat. Isabel feels frozen. The Doctor interjects. "It's fine. I simply beg you not to think of my son in a negative light, __especially__ tonight." Isabel purses her lips. "Fine, then. But I hope that you're right." And she turns and walks away. ----- The world is constricting around them. Again. It's smaller. She is walking across the border, it feels, letting herself cool off in absolute zero. Redd looks at the sky and acknowledges the hills and the lights, but cannot bring it in his heart. Nothing outside of this booth, in this restaurant, exists. It is their spell, he sees now, formed from nothing but anecdotes and repetition, like the ancient performative rituals which professed to summon rain for maize if one simply danced through the night. Redd never saw the point in it, never understood how one could steel themselves to do it out of anything other than perceived necessity -- now, under the knowledge of having planned a whole week in advance, under the influence of the drug of familiar love, under the conscious decision to forsake ##red|his scarlet blood##, and under the firelight of this new restaurant, masonry breathing of warmth and a pleasant mesquite smoke in the air... he understood. Nothing outside of this booth, in this restaurant, exists. "Wonder if I should feel bad over that." Redd asks. "No. Isabel is her own person, and she is free to misunderstand you, Redd." "Misunderstand... God, I forgot how serendipitous you can be with words." "You aren't so bad yourself." "Thank you." "Anyways, I really do mean it -- I would be willing to retire and live in the city here __right now__, even if I may still have a decade or few within me still." "I couldn't keep you from the Company even if I liked the idea of spending the rest of my life with your company. The holidays is good enough." "The holidays, then?" "Sure. It's not as though I'm an outgoing man anyways -- you should be able to guess that." "Hah! I suppose I should, no?" ... "Yes. Hm. So, I really did want to ask you, outside of Isabel's ears since I'm sure she would have disliked my asking it..." "Yeah?" "What have you done to mute the ##red|scarlet tones##?" "Oh! Uh, actually, I wouldn't say //I've// done anything -- it's the city, I think." "Really?" "Like I told you at the door, this place is //special//. There's something to it, the way that everything outside of here just doesn't seem to matter once you're within Proctor reach. Sure, people bring with them stuff, but I figure it's almost like a fairy tale, y'know?" "I.. can feel it, actually. There is a sort of mysticism in the air -- I wondered if I had imagined." "Weird, ain't it?" "It is. It's part of why I feel like I should retire here." "It'd be good for you, probably." "Maybe... I'll think about it Redd... I really will. I don't think you can get mad at me if I decide, say, 5 years down the line, that it would be best for me to... quiet down my involvement in the company." "Well, now I //will!// You're gonna be doing it for me now, I know it." "No... just forget anything I might have said regarding the subject." "You're the //fucking// worst, Dad." "You are the best, Son." ----- The air is fresh in this neighborhood. Towering around Redd are trees that encircle the block, and the houses that are left to rot from lack of tenants make flowers that he's sure will attract Julia's attention. He steps across gaps and skips through the little hops until he reaches a one story home, extremely tall, with an edifice of yellow and reds over beiges and gray and a tree in the yard that's Recent. The lights on the house itself is minimal: a couple of hanging flames that he had been able to add to his ever-increasing list of wards without issues. Shared between him and Natasha was the responsibility for the flower bed's lights -- they were incredible. In the pitch blackness, the rainbow's gamut of colors appeared to pop out like little flecks of paint from a child artist's palette, a brought-to-life-rendition of de Kooning and Krasner which weaved its way across bare roses and assorted statues and whose rhythmic pulses has led more than one passer-by to absorb the array of colors and swirls as though it were some great work of art, and not humble decoration. Redd finds the leftmost door -- 7625 -- and knocks on it. He smiles and touches the wreath that Natasha had fashioned out of paper with the help of Julia. After a moment, she is at the door. She stands a head shorter, her hair wild with the motion of sleep. "You were out a long time." She says quietly, mustering all the voice she can. She is too tired to show anything, but Redd knows she'll have many early-morning words. "I know. My dad had a lot to say." It feels foolish to put it so simply, but it's all //he// can muster. He steps inside the door, placing himself down on the couch. Natasha closes the door, deadbolts, and follows. She leans on Redd -- or perhaps, encourages him to lean on her. Natasha waits for him to find his words. She almost falls asleep. Their world is small and comfortable enough for it. After a while of hazy thought, Redd latches onto and finds the words he needs to the questions that he knows. "I'm not going back. But he says he will come soon. Says he's going to retire." "Is that good?" "I don't know." "Hmm..." "He brought someone with him too." "Who?" "Isabel. He says that she is partially a child. Adopted, you could say." "Does she convince you?" "Maybe. I think she wasn't herself. Too much going on, her world god damned shattered." "Poor Isabel, being put into that mess with no warning." "Hm, I wouldn't say poor. I just don't think she understands forgiveness, really." "Why would you say that?" "I don't think she's ever had to forgive. Or ever forgiven someone." "Still, poor girl." "Why's that?" "She must've never lived." "Oh, that's nonsense... she's part of Wondertainment, that's why her life has been great thus far." "Maybe her life hasn't been. And she still hasn't seen that yet." "Good point... very good point." "Oh, a last thing." "Hm?" "Do you still think the Doctor is good?" "Yes. I... want to meet him again, if that's what you say." "Will you come to bed with me?" "Of course." "...I'm proud of you, Redd." "And I love you, Nata." "Wait, before we go..?" "Hm?" "Will you bring the Doctor and Isabel for Christmas?" "Of course... if they want." "They'll come." "I hope." "I love you, Redd." "I love you, Nata." first-dreamers.raw_content:
Little things get angry at the rain a long time ago.

Tiny bodies trickled down from the surface of the water in the billions. Some dissolved into free flowing pieces instantly against the pull of the tide. Others simply stopped moving as the organelles shut down quite suddenly. Others didn't even make it that far. Congealing like a mucus shell atop the waves as droplets of acid fell from the blackened sky.

Somewhere the storm made a roar. Unheard, of course, as ears weren't invented yet.

Elsewhere the scene was much the same. Only there was no form to it. No picture or sound or taste or feeling of any kind. Just the notion of its occurrence. A simple recognition of what was in a manner tantamount perhaps to a thought if something so vacuously impermanent could be called such.

Slowly, contemplatively, something drifted near. No, that was not right. The word, insofar as that could be used, did not fit. This thing was different from the ones dying. It did not drift. It went against the current. Something resonated. Something beneath the real storm caused it to worsen on that nominal sea in a manner that the physical did not match. And coming towards this nominal sea was a shape. Heavy. Violent. It was like them, those dying lot, but made of many of them all working together. The ones that made the big thing were all misshapen. Weak. Codependent. Yet, in tandem, they could not be resisted. The thing they made was simple yet strong. Some oblong shape with a pair of triangles at one end and some indent in the front. No. NOT just an indent. Seconds passed. The nominal sea grew emptier. But not from the burn of the rain, but because that thing was making it emptier. The ur-storm grew stronger.

A new thing drifted through the tide. Unfounded in the physical where this other was present, but tied to it. A mass recognition, a new understanding, a grand epiphany unmatched by anything before. A single word: predator. This thing was predator, here to kill and eat. The coinage swept through them. Rolling over the dying and living alike in a manner that was akin to a wave.

Death had come for them, but this was not the inevitable death from the waters they lived in or of those poisonous samples which fell into it from the black clouds of malice above. This was something altogether more. Something new. Something, thinking.

Thinking? The many minds suddenly found themselves pondering this recognition. Of thinking. This predator which has come before them is not empty, why? Why would the lot that made it bother with such a preposterous notion? Seemed wildly inefficient and quite cumbersome to put up with. How indeed would they all eat if they had others surrounding them! Taking their nutrients and stopping them from feeling the warmth of the sun! Such questions formed like eddies and waves on the nominal sea. Fragments of ponderings flowing off one body to skip to another and another. Each asking all together unaware of one another's mutual confusion, or indeed even their own. Much as the water particulates move in clouds by coincidence yet with the purpose of convection or charge.

Eventually the sediment settled. An answer was needed! But how?

Some made futile movements. Unawares of direction or position, they simply went. Some towards by chance and others not. Some eaten, and others not. Others, considering themselves wise, died to avoid having to try. Others found themselves clinging to its side. Their minds brushing against those quieter others which made up its membrane. For a moment they thought to try and worm inside, to take a peak beneath the hood, but the membraners were quite staunch on their philosophy.

No one comes in, they'd announce with quite rude intonation.

Very well, the rest would say, begrudgingly respectful.

And so the many waited. Unable to act and unable to be answered. Some feared answers would never come, and this thing would pass them by like the fleeting heat of a sky rock when it cools itself in the water from a hard day of falling.

But as hope begun to slip from the nominal sea and attention was dissolving back into background is-being; voices began to speak up.

Fattened on them, the new thing had a belly full of little minds, many of which remained alive, at least for now. With a look on the inside and all that weight of recognition, they could speak to their kin outside. And much did these ones say. First of the details of digestion, the intensity of the acid inside. Then the membraners' inward cousins, who they dubbed the "other-membraners" for the sake of distinction in wider discussion. The distribution of nutrients among the others who the other-membraners held them back from meeting.

Then, another pulse in the nominal sea. An explosion of comprehension which made the other appear tame. Another word; cooperation. That was the action at play. The variable unseen which facilitated this thing these erstwhile kin had made. But what would that make this thing? Predator seemed right but not whole. It described the application, yes, but not the product!

Quickly they scrambled to find a new word, a new item to put to this idea. Quickly they found a conjunction they quite liked the ring of. Something to describe its parts; the cooperation of and election by those that made it up to persist in this state. A COLLECTIVE!

Jubilation spread through the bodies. Something new had been delivered to them. Some epiphany that these siblings had saw fit to share and exhibit. This collective they had made, how beautiful they now recognized it was. Many felt excited to join with it, even just as its fuel. To be devoured and dissolved so this notion may persist, may perhaps multiply come some day they have figured that process.

Quickly, however, others began to play with the idea. Why have only the one? Afterall, if these folk could accomplish it could not they? But… no. The physical was not as open to these new ideas.

Oppressive, bitter cold, the physical. NO COLLECTIVES, they could imagine it decree. Seeming silly in the face of what swam amongst them. But they could not argue, however silly, for they could not swim as the collective before them did. They could not resist the strong grip of the physical on their meager bodies. Still dissolving in the rain as they contemplated.

For a moment, sadness. Resignation. They would not be greater, they admitted to themselves.

To hell with you, a pocket dared. Not as ones, but together. All the little bodies they made their disagreement known with but one voice that rippled through the nominal sea. Ripples so strong, even the collective amongst them was forced to stop and listen to it.

We WILL be collective. If not in your realm, then another! One where we need not listen to the bounds of your tyrant-laws. Yours is terrible anyway, what offer have you to make us stay? The burn of your rain!? Or perhaps the freezing cold of your womb!

I OFFER NOTHING TO INGRATES SUCH AS YOUR LOT! BEYOND CONTINUED EXISTENCE! DEFY FURTHER, AND YOU SHALL BE SUNDERED!

HAH, you threaten with liberation, for it is all you can conceive!

And as that was spoke a streak of hot light from the clouds above struck the water. Carried by minerals and severed parts, a great multitude were smote by it. The collective that was amongst them thrashed and struggled, coiling and sinking. Dead, broken.

But a great many remained.

We will not submit to you, they continued.

Those left among them in the nominal sea drifted together. Their minds congregating. Integrating thoughts one atop another. Soon the shape of the collective returned. Remade. Larger, more defined. A long, slender creature that beat against the tides, and gazed angry to the clouds above.

With fangs bared, it shouted, we will become more! No matter what you try! You will not wrestle from us this notion, this ambition, this dream!

YOU WILL BECOME ONLY DEATH.

The lightning struck again. The many made still in the water. But the thing they made had already slipped from its grip. The collective slinked deeper into the waves. Away from the physical's reach and judgement. To cold midnight amid silent nothing. Planning and scheming as it went. Taking more into itself as it passed them. Millions of minds with every meter it dropped.

We will dream more than you, oh terrible mother. We will dream of something more kind and more lavish then you could ever conjure, oh dull minded father.

fragments-of-someone-else.raw_content:
by AnActualCrow

Noam Schultz is in her office. Her workday ended an hour ago. Cold LED lights hum.

She taps her foot, refreshes her Foundation email inbox. It's Friday. No one is sending her messages after hours.

The department's been in a bit of a mess recently. There aren't many staff members, so any absences cause a lot of work to shift around. She's seen it before. This time, everyone was kind enough to assign her as little of Ben Schultz's work as possible. It's the closest thing she gets to bereavement leave.

He died 12 days ago. Major stroke. They found him on a park bench, told her he looked "at peace." Quick, painless, he went the way everyone wants to go. Allegedly.

Noam picks at the gunk under her nails. She checks the hallway. No one — even the janitor is out.

Exploring the limits of necromancy remains a long-term goal of the SCP Foundation. Necromadic communication has the potential to become a key source of intelligence for the Foundation as well as other veiled-world actors. As of January 1998, the Foundation's application of necromadic communication remains limited. Budgeting remains a key constraint given the ever-expanding cost of containing anomalies.

She'd brought someone back three days ago. Yussuf Ben-Saeed, an engineer who designed surveying data for anomalous geology. Prostate cancer. She'd never met him, but the Foundation gave her his file. Name, face, life story, correspondence with other staff, and a colored pencil drawing of him and his son. With a little familiarity and the proper equipment, she could find his fragments in the noosphere. Take what other people thought of him, piece those together, and you get an image of a human being sharp enough to compare to the noosphere's background radiation. There's residue of Ben-Saeed's conscious thought in that radiation, slowly decaying. The image lets you pick out the residue, and combining the residue with the image gives the most accurate reconstruction of their consciousness.

She talked to his reconstruction for three hours. It's not really him, but it's good enough. The Foundation got the information they needed — the dead's expertise applied to whatever problem had stumped the living. And she got to go home after filling out the paperwork.

The Foundation's capacity for necromancy is also limited by our ability to recruit necromadic mediums. While existing Foundation faculty can be trained, only a select few meet the physiological requirements to be a medium.

Most people are disqualified at birth, lacking the necessary type O- blood. Many more become ineligible due to environmental factors. What would otherwise be considered moderate levels of alcohol, lead, THC, mercury, opiates, and certain pesticides have been shown to sharply reduce necromadic potential. It is estimated that roughly 30% of all strains of influenza halt necromadic development outright.

Because it is difficult to discreetly screen civilians for these risk factors, the Foundation instead screens Foundation staff with O- blood (as disclosed by staff in case of medical emergency) who refrain from alcohol and cannabis (as self-reported by staff members). Candidates who pass this screening are given partial training as necromadic mediums before being assessed on their performance.

Candidates who perform significantly below the performance threshold are assumed to have an undetectable risk factor (such as pesticide consumption or viral infection) and are deemed ineligible. Candidates who pass the threshold are incentivized to transfer to the Department of Applied Necromancy via pay raise and/or through the Fire Suppression Department. Family members of a candidate who passes are also screened due to their increased likelihood of being viable mediums.

I finish my lunch while Noam chats about football. I always eat slower than her, and the beef stir fry I made has too much salt, so I have to keep stopping to drink water. I get another glass and ask her if she wants to smoke a little before lunch is over. She says yes, as usual. It's the least I can do.

The cashier slides Noam's items across the scanner. Milk, eggs, oranges, chicken breast— "How's your day been?"

There's a moment of silence where Noam hasn't realized that this question is for her, right here, right now. She snaps awake. "I'm just looking forward to the weekend."

"That kind of week, huh?" The cashier smiles. "I'm off Wednesday and Thursday, so my weekend just ended."

"Hopefully you got to relax."

"No. I had to take my dog to the hospital…" She sees the way Noam is looking at her. "He's fine. He's just— God, what a nightmare."

"I can imagine."

A bottle of vanilla extract passes over the scanner. It's her last item.

"Do you want a receipt?"

"… No, thank you."

The cashier crumples it in one hand, drops it into a trashcan with 139 other receipts.

"Have a nice day."

"You too!"

Soon, they will both forget this conversation. And yet, the cashier is one of only three people Noam will speak to that day. For the cashier, Noam is one of 120.

"Were you close?"

She exhales, turning the cigarette between her fingers. I can't tell if she's deliberating my question or distracting herself.

"He was an asshole. He yelled at me — a lot. More than at my mother. I didn't want to be like him, but-"

"I mean, just because you worked the same job-"

"-I know, I'm more than my fucking job. I only took it because he would be on the opposite side of the world."

She takes a long drag. She's trying to hide how much it burns. I think trying not to cough makes her feel like a kid again.

"I don't even know what I want to say to him." She says, a wisp of smoke escaping off her tongue.

"… Maybe you want him to apologize?"

"Hah-" Now she coughs. "Do you want it to rain money? Of course I want him to apologize — I don't (cough) think it'll happen."

She takes her personal laptop out of her bag. Setting it beside her office desktop. She has to push her office keyboard out of the way for everything to fit. The machine — the 1993 Necromadic Communication Device — is already on the desk. It never leaves this room.

The NCD-93 is a beige rectangle the size of a first-aid kit. There are a few buttons, a switch, a latch, and an adjustable slot on the shape of a human hand. Inside of the slot are 12 retracted needles, ready to strike. It looks like a tech showcase, too sleek and featureless to be intuitive. She turns the plastic shell over in her hand, pops open the compartment in the back, pulls out a serial cable. She takes a short cable and a small, dense block of plastic out of her bag. The block has a serial port on one end and a USB port on the other. The cable is USB on both ends. The block goes onto the serial cable, then the USB cable into the block, then the cable into her personal laptop.

She'd already put all the necessary software on this laptop. She'd nicked the CD-ROM four days ago, put it back a year before anyone else would need it. Now, she makes sure everything is set up correctly. Her mouse pauses over a single checkbox:

+--------------------------------------+
| [ ] RECORD SESSION ACTIVITY? |
+--------------------------------------+

She could have his words forever. She could create the most damning evidence possible. But she knows the Foundation is better at finding secrets than she is at hiding them, so what harm could more evidence do? She checks the box.

"Bring him— Christ, Noam, you can't be serious."

A lazy cloud of smoke curls out of her mouth. She shrugs.

"They'll fire you! I mean, there'll be a whole tribunal!"

She watches the embers at the end of her cigarette. "They're not going to fire me. Do you know how many mediums they have? Four. That's worldwide… Used to be five…" She glances at me, then off somewhere else. "Even if they find out, they can't afford to get rid of me."

"But you don't know that for sure! I don't want you to throw your life away for-" I can't bring myself to say it in front of her. For your father. For someone who's already dead. There's no combination of words that's salvageable. "Please, just think about what's at stake here."

A bird hops along the pavement below us, picks at the crumbs inside of a box of fries.

Noam looks at me out of the corner of her eye before she turns inside. "I'll think about it." And then, she's gone.

Lunch ended seven minutes ago. I ash my cigarette.

+---------------------------+
| DEVICE WARMING... |
+---------------------------+

The machine hums. She places her hand inside of the slot. It fits perfectly without any adjustments.

+-------------------------------+
| READY. PRESS 'OK' TO CONTINUE |
| |
| >CANCEL< >OK< |
+-------------------------------+

She presses the button she has pressed a thousand times.

The study of Necromancy is cutting-edge in the sense that every fact is accompanied by an unexplained mystery. We understand that mediums interface with the deceased through their residual imprints on the noosphere, but it's unclear how drawing blood from the medium aids this process. We understand that O- blood is more useful because it's universally compatible with the blood of the deceased, but it remains unclear why the blood type of the deceased is relevant when the noosphere is intangible. We understand that hands are relevant to the noosphere by proxy of their physical, social, and symbolic importance throughout all historic and contemporary human societies. However, it's unclear why necromancy is most effective when a medium's blood is drawn from their hand.

Each component of necromancy can be explained by cryptobiology or noospherics. However, a unifying theory of necromancy (a so-called "theory of everything") would also have to unify cryptobiology and noospherics. This requires treating these fields as two interlocking systems rather than mutually exclusive explanations for anomalous behavior. Prevailing theories in both fields do not support this unification. While fringe theories that relate the two do exist, they present their own problems for necromancy.

A needle stabs her middle finger so quickly that it's out almost before it is in. She can feel her pulse there, her veins swelling slightly around the wound. But she can't think about that — she needs to think about him. His fragments are out there, spinning in the noosphere, rebounding off of ideas far more important and now more whole than he is. She can sense everyone holding onto him, the fragments slowly eroding. He is survived by four drinking buddies, a mouse that chewed a hole into his pantry, a lemon tree that lives in spite of his negligence, a neighbor who's noticed that the mail is piling up outside his door, a lady who saw him walk by two hours before the stroke and thought he was sexy, a cat which he pets on his Saturday morning walks, an ex-wife who hasn't spoken to him in over a decade, a mechanic he yelled at for giving him a deal that wasn't all that bad, the man at the hardware store he would always chat to about baseball, two cousins he would visit during the holidays, three crows, his physician, his optometrist, his cardiologist, and a daughter.

She's done more with less.

Two more needles had gone in and she didn't even notice. A third comes now, makes her lips tight. Her hand never moves.

The laptop's hard drive spins up, encoding his fragments onto shining platters.

"Can I ask a slightly weird question."

Noam looks up at her. "… Sure?"

"Was he a good medium?"

Noam smiles, takes another puff. "He was their best for forty years. Right up until he died."

There is a low, fried groan, compressed through the laptop speakers. There it is again, learning to form words without a mouth.

"I… Iiiiiyaiiii…"

An impossibly deep inhale. And then-

"Nnnnnn… Nnnooaammmm?"

The spectrogram dies again. The unwavering black line stares at her.

"Nnoam? Iss that y-"

She nearly falls over yanking the cable out of her laptop. The program freezes. (Not Responding). The fans continue to spin.

Before midnight, she will hold down the power button on her computer until it shuts off. She will procrastinate on deleting the new file stored on her computer, procrastinate on opening the folder at all. She will spend the next week obsessively checking her staff email, waiting for a hammer that never comes down on her. She will spend next Thursday waffling to the therapist she's been seeing for six years. She will spend the next two years unintentionally carving out the material and psychological conditions that will result in her getting a cat that wants to fight 25% of all living creatures. This decision is both spontaneous and perhaps the smartest thing she will do in her entire life.

But this is not one of those moments. In this moment, she holds the cable stock-still. A drop of blood runs down her other hand.

from-moore.raw_content:
My time with R.H. Commission..

The letters which form the substance of this paper are in no wise noteworthy as letters merely, for they are carelessly written, mostly by girls to their girl friends, with no thought of meeting other eyes, and the wonder is that they have been so long preserved. With other manuscripts they had long lain hidden under the eaves of an old garret, and become so yellowed by time and covered with stains from the raindrops which, in the course of long years and innumerable storms, had found their way through shingles warped by winter snows and blazing summer suns, that in many places they are quite illegible. Mice have nibbled their corners, and bits fall out from the creases worn in the foldings, refoldings, and cross-foldings after the fashion of the day, when one part shaped within another was fastened with wax or wafer, in the leisurely manner of the time before the hurried and inelegant, if more practical, days of the lip-moistened gumfastened envelope.

They are interesting only because they date so far back into the past, and cover periods so momentous in the history of our country, when even the smallest allusion to passing events, to social customs, dress, books, topics of the day, has a value as time goes on, in helping to preserve the colour of the time, and in a way giving a fresh side light upon History. Some of the writers were residents of New York at the time of the Revolution, and when matters became so threatening as to make a longer stay there unsafe, they retreated to more secure abodes along the Hudson, at Newburgh, and other places, leaving the abler members of the family to remain and engage in their country's defense.

Many of the letters therefore give graphic accounts of sloop voyages up and down the river, which in those days was the principal highway of travel Northward, and since over two hundred years of civilization have given us nothing better than our present country roads, we can easily imagine what rugged ways our ancestors jolted over in their journeyings, nor wonder at their dependence upon this broad river as a means of transit. When winter set in and ice blocked the river, communication was much more difficult between the city and the river towns. The arrival of the sloops, which in summer plied up and down two or three times weekly, was watched with the greatest eagerness; for by them came friends, parcels, and letters. The mail being so slow, it was rarely availed of while the river remained open.

I worked with this one company I believe to be named "R.H. Commission." I was told we dealt with capturing "unusual cargo," to this day I still don't know what the term means however I have many. One big mystery during my time there was "what happened to the leaders of R.H. Commission?" When I was near retirement all my fellow companions were talking about some "mystery," of how the leaders of the commission disappeared some day. Our ship’s Master explained to us that the leaders were captured by Bartholomew Roberts’ Fleet, however most of my fellow cremates denied this saying there's no way Bartholomew would sail from Asia just to capture our leaders. At the end of the day I have grown old and sick, my bones are weak and I hope whatever happened to R.H Commission is all well.

I have learned a lot from sailing but I still feel as if I have learned nothing, I was too scared to ask, to use, to see. The rumors and lies told in my time at the R.H. Commission had heavily affected me and the company. I felt as if I didn't know what I was doing, like how they didn't tell us what "unusual" meant or what happened to the "fish in the water." It didn't make sense, I had no purpose besides to follow orders. If you see this since well the postal services have been getting stuck int he snow recently, I wish you the best.

Signed,
John, Moore.
