the-sleep.raw_content:
Will Site-169 survive the sleep?

The Day It Happened

Director Amelie Metanoia sits at her desk, staring at the computer screen with a document consisting of only two words: this sucks. It, indeed, sucks to be in her position as of this moment. Directing an entire division that the majority of the Foundation looks at with disdain does wonders for a person. But that doesn’t matter. All that matters is that her family is safe. That everything she worked hard for is intact. And the anomalies are treated as they should be, as people with various needs that must be met.

She’s seen the horrors lurking in the darkness. All the worst containment breaches that any researcher can think of. But these breaches can all be prevented by one simple fix, that being to improve the quality of life not only for the researchers working tirelessly to defend the world but also for the SCPs that they contain.

So she carries on. She does what needs to be done for a better world for all walks of life. At the moment, the current issue is convincing the Overseers to approve an increase of their budget.

And she has nothing.

As Amelie ponders for the fourteenth time about how she can further do nothing and make a convincing argument out of thin air, she hears the laughter of the children from down the hall. Their joy never ceases to brighten her day. Brandon with his ability to pull his eyes out of his sockets while juggling them, Julia with her fire breath, Angelica with the way that she can turn an entire room into a magical wonderland with a snap of her fingers. They’re all so extraordinary. Amelie can’t fathom a world not enriched by their presence and their kindness.

Back to the paper now, no distractions. There can’t be any more distractions.

She focuses on something else instead. The clock on the wall behind her ticks and ticks and ticks, pounding its cyclic rhythm into her skull and forcing her to drown out the other sounds in the room.

The tiresome mundanity of her procrastination then clashes with the boring reality of her daily life, creating a paradox that finally frees her to start being productive.

Now she’s back in business. Amelie starts by working on the spreadsheet, then switching tabs to work on the main document itself, then to another tab to work on the outline of the email that she’ll send to the Overseers, then back to the spreadsheet. Back and forth and back and forth, no longer concerned about the future of the division, or the fact of the sudden silence outside, or the many shouting matches that she has with Feghoot, or that damn buzzing from the AC, or—

She jolts from her productive trance. The sound of the air circulating above her is the only thing that can be heard. No voices, no footsteps. Nothing.

Amelie can’t hear the children.

Then she hears the screaming and shouting in the distance, the hollering and stomping of boots from the security personnel, a cavalcade of outright panic from those of 169 who are not prepared for catastrophes at this scale. There has never been a more intense and constricting feeling in Amelie’s chest since she first founded the division until this very moment.

She springs up from her chair, knocking it over as she rushes out the door and sprints down the hallway towards the commons area and the mess hall.

A common sight of a room in complete disarray is usually the cramped crowds pushing and shoving over each other as they try to escape the chaos afoot, even trampling others unfortunate enough to be caught in the eye of the storm. What she doesn’t expect are the fistfights, or the shouting matches between the anomalies and staff pointing fingers at each other, or Kirby Case failing to keep the situation from unraveling no matter how hard they try to dampen the hostilities. An outright brawl like this is unheard of at a site like 169.

Amelie attempts to make her way over to Kirby before she is interrupted by the sound of someone calling her name. She turns to her left to see a familiar thaumaturgist with a puffy green coat and an inexplicably furious look on his face.

Cole V. Filverent approaches her with eyes like burning matches, before grabbing her by the lapels and pulling her face to face. “What did you do?”

Amelie calmly but firmly breaks his grip off her. “Hey. I didn’t do anything. Nobody’s done anything.”

He pauses before breaking off the tension between them. “Sorry. But there’s something wrong with Polly.”

“What’s going on?”

“I can’t hear her anymore. All I hear is quacking. I kept asking her if she’s okay, but she’s not answering me. I need to know what’s going on.” His voice starts to shake with every word.

Amelie puts her hand on his shoulder. “That’s what I’m trying to figure out too. I’m as in the dark as you are. But once we get our bearings, then I can help you and help everyone else. We’ll get through this together, okay?”

He hangs his head. “Okay.”

Somewhere within the site’s Playground, Polly Filverent has no reason to object that she’s a duck and not a person in the form of a duck, as she doesn’t understand the distinction between the two or any kind of human language.

Amelie turns her attention back to Kirby, seeing that they are struggling to keep the masses at bay. She rushes over to their side, and they give a nod in acknowledgment.

“What’s our status?” Amelie asks.

There’s a silence in the air, overwhelming over the raucous violence. Kirby looks at her with a blank stare, the life in their eyes dissipating before her very sight.

“They’re gone, Amy. The kids are gone,” they state in a monotone tone, like they’re reading off an obituary.

Amelie can feel her stomach drop to the floor, but right now there’s no time for processing what has just been said. She considers her options, before formulating a concrete plan.

“Can I borrow your megaphone?”

“What for?”

Amelie gestures toward the mass of people. “These people need a voice of reason. And I’m usually the one to fill that role.”

“Fair enough.” They toss their megaphone to her, and she catches it with grace.

A shout is heard by the raging masses, barely able to be recognized but the message is clear. They turn their attention to the source.

“Look. I know how difficult this is for all of us right now. We are all horrified, and rightfully so, but we can’t solve this by pinning the blame on someone else. None of us know what’s going on. Not me, not Melissa, not Kirby, not even Moses Feghoot, that ol’ grouch. But we can get through this, like we always have,” she elucidates, her public speaking skills that she learned getting their time to shine.

One man steps from the crowd to face her. She recognizes him as the one who has his arms and hands lacking skin and muscle tissue, leaving the skeleton behind. Or had, considering that his arms now appear to match the rest of his body.

“You can fix this, right? Right?” he pleads to her, the horror so clearly seen on his face with the realization that he has lost something important to him.

“We’re going to assess what’s been lost, convene with other sites to see who else is affected, and then we can help each other out to stay afloat in spite of this crisis. We can all use some mutual aid right about now.”

“But can you reverse it?” His expression changes to one of agitation.

“Well—”

She’s interrupted by a voice from the crowd. “She can’t, Fred! None of them can. The Foundation isn’t going to do anything about it. I know they won’t.”

Amelie takes a deep breath, before continuing. “Regardless of what they do, we’re not going to sit around and twiddle our thumbs while you all suffer. That’s not in our motto. I’ll never let any of you get left behind. Never.”

Kirby taps on her shoulder, and she relinquishes the megaphone to them. “Alright folks, simmer down, simmer down. Let’s get this mess cleaned up.”

When the crowd disperses and the two catch up on both of their perspectives and what they each saw, they discuss what to do and eventually settle on having a meeting with the rest of the Caretakers and administrative staff.

They all scramble and pile up into the meeting room, some looking worse for wear than others, and they each sit in their respective seats. A long, uncomfortable silence goes by before someone speaks up.

“So. Any ideas for what we should be doing?” Melissa Mayfield looks as if she’s been through three all-nighters in a row.

Kirby glares around the room, folding their arms over their legs and shrinking down to make themselves smaller. “Let’s just contact the others and get this over with.”

Amelie nods her head, then hesitates. “We should keep in touch with the other sites, but I’m worried about our friends. Their safety should be our number one priority, and something this terrible is going to take a lot more than a toll on them.”

“True.” Melissa turns her head to the site director. “What about you, Moses?”

The director doesn’t respond. Amelie sees a man with a thousand-yard stare, eyes boring into her skull, like he’s seen something that isn’t meant to be seen. Like he’s seen death itself riding on its white horse, to reap what it sows.

She imagines him shrugging off the whole affair, or even celebrating it in her most bad faith interpretation. But none of that aligns with reality. She’s never seen him like this. Never seen him this afraid.

It can’t be the Moses Feghoot that she knows. Not with those eyes.

Now

Amelie Metanoia, former director of the now defunct Anomalous Entity Engagement Division, sits on her bed in her newly leased apartment, typing the latest draft for a grant proposal to help fund the newest organization that she’s working with. She’s done work with a lot of charities, and has volunteered at homeless shelters, food pantries, blood drives, animal shelters, and has worked to support children in need. Name a non-profit organization off the top of your head, and Amelie has most likely worked with them. She’s done it all.

And yet it’s not enough. Not enough to fulfill that promise that she made to her family all those years ago.

Kirby Case now works as a security guard at a warehouse some miles off from where Amelie lives. They still chat from time to time, but only through her insistent invitations and their reluctance to go along with it. They’ve grown distant from her, for obvious reasons.

Melissa Mayfield currently serves as an occupational therapist, helping other individuals to improve their ability in completing daily tasks, such as getting dressed or using a computer. Unlike Kirby, she and Amelie have become fast friends without the constant pressure of working at the Foundation, and they discuss a plethora of topics including their respective fields.

Moses Feghoot has never been seen again. At least, Amelie has never seen him since that day. Her contact with the withering few remnants of the Foundation has confirmed to her multiple times that he’s still alive and well, but not much else. No traces of his personal life or where he’s been. It almost seems as if he vanished.

Like they all have.

Well, most of them. Some of them have simply lost the magic that made them who they are, that gave the world its beauty in many configurations.

Her pet fish Percy, who had the former designation of SCP-2689, now wanders around in a fish bowl on her desk, looking none the wiser of the anomalous attribute that he once held. On some days Amelie wishes that he can make her feel something again, make her feel less like a pathetic stain on the earth, even for just a moment, but that’s never going to happen again. Percy is a blood parrot cichlid. And fish can’t make miracles.

She tries her hardest not to cry. She has to keep going. She can’t stop. Not now. There needs to be more done for the world. For the world that has excised its own wonder and whimsy, forever condemning itself to the bleak reality that it has become. For the people who need support, to feel like they aren’t alone, to feel that they’re loved and cared for. For the ghosts of the past that haunt her each and every day that she can’t ever let down again.

Her phone buzzes in her pocket, and she picks it up and looks at the screen. It’s a text from Melissa. Another request to hang out at their favorite coffee shop, it seems. Eh, why not. It’ll take her mind off things at least.

Amelie packs her things, shoves her shoes on without tying them as she’s too tired to even bother, and makes her way to the car. The ignition starts, and the familiar sound of the car’s engine hissing fills her ears. That problem will have to be solved later, like all the other little dilemmas that slowly accumulate over time to morph into a big pile of inexorable filth that won’t matter, in the end. So what it’s noticeable? So what she can’t take care of herself anymore? That’s nothing compared to what she’s lost.

The grey gloom of the sky above flies past her as the car approaches the cafe. It lacks the bright blue that the kids used to draw in their lovely little sketches. It lacks the fluffy clouds, the bright and shining sun, and the whimsy and imagination that once brought joy in her life.

She parks the car, and heads inside. Melissa is already there, sitting at the booth at the far left corner in the back. Both of their drinks and their usual orders have been set on the table. A common Melissa act of kindness.

Amelie sits across from her. “Hey.”

“Hey, Amy. How’s it hanging?”

“Nothing much.” Her voice sounds unconvincing, but no one’s going to care anyhow.

“You sure?” Melissa asks in concern.

“I’m fine, Mel.”

“I’m here to help if you need anything, you know.”

Amelie gets the urge to sink under the floor. “I don’t need your help. You’re not my therapist, and I don’t need one. Everything’s fine.”

“Whatever it is, we can work through it together and—”

“Just shut up, okay?” She snaps without thinking.

The shift in Melissa’s expression makes her regret it immediately. “Okay. Do you want to talk about something else?”

“Yeah, that would be nice. Sorry.”

Melissa nods. “Well, I was thinking about bringing the gang back together.”

“The gang?” Amelie raises an eyebrow.

“You know, me, you, Kirby, Mos—”

“Kirby wants nothing to do with me anymore, and Moses probably wants to dissociate from us altogether, wherever the hell he’s at.”

Melissa blinks once. “What’s going on with you and Kirby? I thought you guys were like two peas in a pod.”

“Well, when you convince someone in your mission and have them believe in your cause to the point that they’d die for it, and then the world decides on a whim to obliterate the people you’re supposed to protect, what do you think is going to happen? Certainly not being on good terms with them, that’s for sure.”

“You can talk to them, though, right? You can work it out together.”

Amelie waves her arms up and down in exasperation. “If they wanted to talk to me, they would’ve reached out to me. I had to do it for them, because they don’t want to see my face again. And that’s fine, actually! I don’t like me either.”

She knows that look on Melissa’s face. “What do you mean by that?”

“Isn’t it obvious, Mel? I failed all of them. We were supposed to give them hope, help them be free to feel like themselves, and now they’re gone and everyone hates my guts.”

“No one hates you, Amy.”

“I know Kirby does!” Amelie raises her voice.

Melissa takes a big gulp of her coffee, trying to keep it together, before continuing. “I don’t think that’s true at all. They don’t talk about you like that when they’re around me. Maybe you two are getting the wrong ideas about each other, but either way, it’s not your fault. You weren’t the one who caused this.”

“But I promised them that I’d protect them. And they’re gone, Mel. If I ever see any of them again, you know how they’re going to feel about me.”

They sit there in silence for a moment. Amelie fights to not choke herself up, to not let the tears sting her eyes.

Melissa puts her hands on top of hers, to try to ground her out of her emotions. “We did the best we could. You did the best you could. You helped those left to find a safe place to live. You made sure they never went more than a day without needing what they needed the most. Don’t you remember any of that?”

Amelie takes a deep breath. “Yeah, you’re right. But I don’t know if that compares to what we lost. What I lost.”

“You can’t change the past, Amy. All we can do now is carry on and honor them and what they stood for.”

Amelie chuckles at how ironic that is. “As if what they stood for isn’t dead. I killed it, Mel. I should’ve talked to them more, I should’ve been there for them, but you want to know what I did? I kept worrying about spreadsheets and expense reports.”

She stands up to make her point, gesticulating like a passionate lecturer. “Maybe this is anomalous hibernation, or something. They’re all asleep, and they’ll come back one day when the world isn’t a graveyard where dreams go to die. Nothing about what happened makes any goddamn sense at all. Sure, every anomaly got up and went to the farm upstate at the exact same time! That makes perfect sense! Don’t you think that’s anomalous in and of itself? Don’t you think we could’ve done something about that? We could’ve gotten a team, and I would’ve been on that team, and it wouldn’t matter how much sleep I would lose cause I would’ve done it for—”

Melissa grabs her by the shoulder, gesturing to her to sit down. “Hey. You’re going to make a scene. Deep breaths, okay?”

Breathe in, breathe out.

Amelie sits down, ignoring the people that are probably staring at her by now, and looks down at her food for a while, unwilling to even gather the strength to touch it with her fork.

It’s always the question of when. When can she move on from something like this? When can she wake up one day and say that she’s now happy and fulfilled in life? Can she ever be happy anymore?

She’s done the best she can to honor their memory and look forward to the future. But is that future possible without them? Is that possible without the magic of this world that made life worth living? Can there ever be a better future for her or the people that she cared for again?

Melissa watches her with a look of pity. At least, that’s what it looks like to Amelie, who deserves all the judgement given to her.

“I know how hard it is for you right now. It’s hard for me too, but we can’t keep fretting about what we could’ve done. That won’t change the fact that they’re gone. But we can still try to make things better for the people around us. You’ve done so much for so many people, Amy.”

Amelie finally lets the floodgates through and sobs, freeing herself from all the pain that she repressed inside.

“I’m sorry Mel, I’m so sorry…”

The silence that unfolds is unbearable, but it’s better than burdening herself with something that she can’t control.

She wipes the tears from her eyes. “I think I need help. With everything, really. I don’t know what to do.”

“I’ll help you find what you need. You shouldn’t have to bear through this alone.”

“I could’ve fixed things with Kirby, but now I lost what we had too. They looked up to me, you know? And then I just pushed them away,” Amelie admits.

“I don’t think what you did is irreconcilable. It will take time, but they’ll forgive you one day. I know they will,” Melissa promises to her.

“Do you think that they can come back one day? So this can all be over? I need this to be over.”

The next thing she speaks to her is the most honest thing that she can say. “I don’t know, Amy. I really don’t. But we have each other, and that’s good enough for me.”

The rest of their lunch passes in silence, before Melissa hurries to get to her next appointment. She gives a quick apology before rushing out the door.

Amelie doesn’t move from her position. She contemplates everything that happened, everything that she’s seen. The children, with so much joy in their hearts and so much love to give, now gone with the wind. The bond that she and the other Caretakers had that’s as strong as a towering oak in a storm, now fallen apart at the seams. Moses Feghoot and his eyes that stare into her soul.

There is no scenario that she can think of where she can move on. Not like this. It’s unfathomable.

The tears return, and Amelie lets them wash her sorrows away. She won’t let the memories that she has of them all ever fade. Their names will be remembered and cherished for as long as she lives.

As she ponders her position in the world and how she can make her work matter, the flowers bloom, the birds are chirping, and there are children who are laughing and making people’s days brighter. She may not know it, but there is still joy hiding beneath the floorboards of these ever-stagnating times.

And the world carries on without her.

the-sleep.raw_source: ===== [[include component:preview text=Will Site-169 survive the sleep? ]] ===== [[module css]] #extra-div-6 {     position: fixed;     top: 0; left: 0;     width: 100%; height: 100%;     -webkit-backdrop-filter: grayscale(100%);     backdrop-filter: grayscale(100%);     z-index: 11;     pointer-events: none; } [[/module]] [[>]] [[module rate]] [[/>]] **The Day It Happened** Director Amelie Metanoia sits at her desk, staring at the computer screen with a document consisting of only two words: //this sucks//. It, indeed, sucks to be in her position as of this moment. Directing an [https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/anomalous-entity-engagement-division-hub entire division] that the majority of the Foundation looks at with disdain does wonders for a person. But that doesn’t matter. All that matters is that her family is safe. That everything she worked hard for is intact. And the anomalies are treated as they should be, as people with various needs that must be met. She’s seen the horrors lurking in the darkness. All the worst containment breaches that any researcher can think of. But these breaches can all be prevented by one simple fix, that being to improve the quality of life not only for the researchers working tirelessly to defend the world but also for the SCPs that they contain. So she carries on. She does what needs to be done for a better world for all walks of life. At the moment, the current issue is convincing the Overseers to approve an increase of their budget. And she has nothing. As Amelie ponders for the fourteenth time about how she can further do nothing and make a convincing argument out of thin air, she hears the laughter of the children from down the hall. Their joy never ceases to brighten her day. Brandon with his ability to pull his eyes out of his sockets while juggling them, Julia with her fire breath, Angelica with the way that she can turn an entire room into a magical wonderland with a snap of her fingers. They’re all so //extraordinary//. Amelie can’t fathom a world not enriched by their presence and their kindness. Back to the paper now, no distractions. There can’t be any more distractions. She focuses on something else instead. The clock on the wall behind her ticks and ticks and ticks, pounding its cyclic rhythm into her skull and forcing her to drown out the other sounds in the room. The tiresome mundanity of her procrastination then clashes with the boring reality of her daily life, creating a paradox that finally frees her to start being productive. Now she’s back in business. Amelie starts by working on the spreadsheet, then switching tabs to work on the main document itself, then to another tab to work on the outline of the email that she’ll send to the Overseers, then back to the spreadsheet. Back and forth and back and forth, no longer concerned about the future of the division, or the fact of the sudden silence outside, or the many shouting matches that she has with Feghoot, or that damn buzzing from the AC, or— She jolts from her productive trance. The sound of the air circulating above her is the only thing that can be heard. No voices, no footsteps. Nothing. Amelie can’t hear the children. Then she hears the screaming and shouting in the distance, the hollering and stomping of boots from the security personnel, a cavalcade of outright panic from those of 169 who are not prepared for catastrophes at this scale. There has never been a more intense and constricting feeling in Amelie’s chest since she first founded the division until this very moment. She springs up from her chair, knocking it over as she rushes out the door and sprints down the hallway towards the commons area and the mess hall. A common sight of a room in complete disarray is usually the cramped crowds pushing and shoving over each other as they try to escape the chaos afoot, even trampling others unfortunate enough to be caught in the eye of the storm. What she doesn’t expect are the fistfights, or the shouting matches between the anomalies and staff pointing fingers at each other, or Kirby Case failing to keep the situation from unraveling no matter how hard they try to dampen the hostilities. An outright brawl like this is unheard of at a site like 169. Amelie attempts to make her way over to Kirby before she is interrupted by the sound of someone calling her name. She turns to her left to see a familiar thaumaturgist with a puffy green coat and an inexplicably furious look on his face. [[[SCP-6714| Cole V. Filverent]]] approaches her with eyes like burning matches, before grabbing her by the lapels and pulling her face to face. “What //did you do?//” Amelie calmly but firmly breaks his grip off her. “Hey. I didn’t do anything. Nobody’s done anything.” He pauses before breaking off the tension between them. “Sorry. But there’s something wrong with Polly.” “What’s going on?” “I can’t hear her anymore. All I hear is quacking. I kept asking her if she’s okay, but she’s not answering me. I need to know what’s going on.” His voice starts to shake with every word. Amelie puts her hand on his shoulder. “That’s what I’m trying to figure out too. I’m as in the dark as you are. But once we get our bearings, then I can help you and help everyone else. We’ll get through this together, okay?” He hangs his head. “Okay.” Somewhere within the site’s Playground, Polly Filverent has no reason to object that she’s a duck and not a person in the form of a duck, as she doesn’t understand the distinction between the two or any kind of human language. Amelie turns her attention back to Kirby, seeing that they are struggling to keep the masses at bay. She rushes over to their side, and they give a nod in acknowledgment. “What’s our status?” Amelie asks. There’s a silence in the air, overwhelming over the raucous violence. Kirby looks at her with a blank stare, the life in their eyes dissipating before her very sight. “They’re gone, Amy. The kids are gone,” they state in a monotone tone, like they’re reading off an obituary. Amelie can feel her stomach drop to the floor, but right now there’s no time for processing what has just been said. She considers her options, before formulating a concrete plan. “Can I borrow your megaphone?” “What for?” Amelie gestures toward the mass of people. “These people need a voice of reason. And I’m usually the one to fill that role.” “Fair enough.” They toss their megaphone to her, and she catches it with grace. A shout is heard by the raging masses, barely able to be recognized but the message is clear. They turn their attention to the source. “Look. I know how difficult this is for all of us right now. We are all horrified, and rightfully so, but we can’t solve this by pinning the blame on someone else. None of us know what’s going on. Not me, not Melissa, not Kirby, not even Moses Feghoot, that ol’ grouch. But we can get through this, like we always have,” she elucidates, her public speaking skills that she learned getting their time to shine. One man steps from the crowd to face her. She recognizes him as the one who has his arms and hands lacking skin and muscle tissue, leaving the skeleton behind. Or had, considering that his arms now appear to match the rest of his body. “You can fix this, right? Right?” he pleads to her, the horror so clearly seen on his face with the realization that he has lost something important to him. “We’re going to assess what’s been lost, convene with other sites to see who else is affected, and then we can help each other out to stay afloat in spite of this crisis. We can all use some mutual aid right about now.” “But can you reverse it?” His expression changes to one of agitation. “Well—” She’s interrupted by a voice from the crowd. “She can’t, Fred! None of them can. The Foundation isn’t going to do anything about it. //I know they won’t//.” Amelie takes a deep breath, before continuing. “Regardless of what they do, we’re not going to sit around and twiddle our thumbs while you all suffer. That’s not in our motto. I’ll never let any of you get left behind. Never.” Kirby taps on her shoulder, and she relinquishes the megaphone to them. “Alright folks, simmer down, simmer down. Let’s get this mess cleaned up.” When the crowd disperses and the two catch up on both of their perspectives and what they each saw, they discuss what to do and eventually settle on having a meeting with the rest of the Caretakers and administrative staff. They all scramble and pile up into the meeting room, some looking worse for wear than others, and they each sit in their respective seats. A long, uncomfortable silence goes by before someone speaks up. “So. Any ideas for what we should be doing?” Melissa Mayfield looks as if she’s been through three all-nighters in a row. Kirby glares around the room, folding their arms over their legs and shrinking down to make themselves smaller. “Let’s just contact the others and get this over with.” Amelie nods her head, then hesitates. “We should keep in touch with the other sites, but I’m worried about our friends. Their safety should be our number one priority, and something this terrible is going to take a lot more than a toll on them.” “True.” Melissa turns her head to the site director. “What about you, Moses?” The director doesn’t respond. Amelie sees a man with a thousand-yard stare, eyes boring into her skull, like he’s seen something that isn’t meant to be seen. Like he’s seen death itself riding on its white horse, to reap what it sows. She imagines him shrugging off the whole affair, or even celebrating it in her most bad faith interpretation. But none of that aligns with reality. She’s never seen him like this. Never seen him this afraid. It can’t be the Moses Feghoot that she knows. Not with those eyes. ---- **Now** Amelie Metanoia, former director of the now defunct Anomalous Entity Engagement Division, sits on her bed in her newly leased apartment, typing the latest draft for a grant proposal to help fund the newest organization that she’s working with. She’s done work with a lot of charities, and has volunteered at homeless shelters, food pantries, blood drives, animal shelters, and has worked to support children in need. Name a non-profit organization off the top of your head, and Amelie has most likely worked with them. She’s done it all. And yet it’s not enough. Not enough to fulfill that promise that she made to her family all those years ago. Kirby Case now works as a security guard at a warehouse some miles off from where Amelie lives. They still chat from time to time, but only through her insistent invitations and their reluctance to go along with it. They’ve grown distant from her, for obvious reasons. Melissa Mayfield currently serves as an occupational therapist, helping other individuals to improve their ability in completing daily tasks, such as getting dressed or using a computer. Unlike Kirby, she and Amelie have become fast friends without the constant pressure of working at the Foundation, and they discuss a plethora of topics including their respective fields. Moses Feghoot has never been seen again. At least, Amelie has never seen him since that day. Her contact with the withering few remnants of the Foundation has confirmed to her multiple times that he’s still alive and well, but not much else. No traces of his personal life or where he’s been. It almost seems as if he vanished. Like they all have. Well, most of them. Some of them have simply lost the magic that made them who they are, that gave the world its beauty in many configurations. Her pet fish Percy, who had the former designation of [[[SCP-2689]]], now wanders around in a fish bowl on her desk, looking none the wiser of the anomalous attribute that he once held. On some days Amelie wishes that he can make her feel something again, make her feel less like a pathetic stain on the earth, even for just a moment, but that’s never going to happen again. Percy is a blood parrot cichlid. And fish can’t make miracles. She tries her hardest not to cry. She has to keep going. She can’t stop. Not now. There needs to be more done for the world. For the world that has excised its own wonder and whimsy, forever condemning itself to the bleak reality that it has become. For the people who need support, to feel like they aren’t alone, to feel that they’re loved and cared for. For the ghosts of the past that haunt her each and every day that she can’t ever let down again. Her phone buzzes in her pocket, and she picks it up and looks at the screen. It’s a text from Melissa. Another request to hang out at their favorite coffee shop, it seems. Eh, why not. It’ll take her mind off things at least. Amelie packs her things, shoves her shoes on without tying them as she’s too tired to even bother, and makes her way to the car. The ignition starts, and the familiar sound of the car’s engine hissing fills her ears. That problem will have to be solved later, like all the other little dilemmas that slowly accumulate over time to morph into a big pile of inexorable filth that won’t matter, in the end. So what it’s noticeable? So what she can’t take care of herself anymore? That’s nothing compared to what she’s lost. The grey gloom of the sky above flies past her as the car approaches the cafe. It lacks the bright blue that the kids used to draw in their lovely little sketches. It lacks the fluffy clouds, the bright and shining sun, and the whimsy and imagination that once brought joy in her life. She parks the car, and heads inside. Melissa is already there, sitting at the booth at the far left corner in the back. Both of their drinks and their usual orders have been set on the table. A common Melissa act of kindness. Amelie sits across from her. “Hey.” “Hey, Amy. How’s it hanging?” “Nothing much.” Her voice sounds unconvincing, but no one’s going to care anyhow. “You sure?” Melissa asks in concern. “I’m fine, Mel.” “I’m here to help if you need anything, you know.” Amelie gets the urge to sink under the floor. “I don’t need your help. You’re not my therapist, and I don’t need one. Everything’s fine.” “Whatever it is, we can work through it together and—” “Just shut up, okay?” She snaps without thinking. The shift in Melissa’s expression makes her regret it immediately. “Okay. Do you want to talk about something else?” “Yeah, that would be nice. Sorry.” Melissa nods. “Well, I was thinking about bringing the gang back together.” “The gang?” Amelie raises an eyebrow. “You know, me, you, Kirby, Mos—” “Kirby wants nothing to do with me anymore, and Moses probably wants to dissociate from us altogether, wherever the hell he’s at.” Melissa blinks once. “What’s going on with you and Kirby? I thought you guys were like two peas in a pod.” “Well, when you convince someone in your mission and have them believe in your cause to the point that they’d die for it, and then the world decides on a whim to obliterate the people you’re supposed to protect, what do you think is going to happen? Certainly not being on good terms with them, that’s for sure.” “You can talk to them, though, right? You can work it out together.” Amelie waves her arms up and down in exasperation. “If they wanted to talk to me, they would’ve reached out to me. I had to do it for them, because they don’t want to see my face again. And that’s fine, actually! I don’t like me either.” She knows that look on Melissa’s face. “What do you mean by that?” “Isn’t it obvious, Mel? I failed all of them. We were supposed to give them hope, help them be free to feel like themselves, and now they’re gone and everyone hates my guts.” “No one hates you, Amy.” “I know Kirby does!” Amelie raises her voice. Melissa takes a big gulp of her coffee, trying to keep it together, before continuing. “I don’t think that’s true at all. They don’t talk about you like that when they’re around me. Maybe you two are getting the wrong ideas about each other, but either way, it’s not your fault. You weren’t the one who caused this.” “But I promised them that I’d protect them. And they’re //gone//, Mel. If I ever see [[[SCP-6245| any]]] [[[SCP-1508| of]]] [[[SCP-8940| them]]] again, you know how they’re going to feel about me.” They sit there in silence for a moment. Amelie fights to not choke herself up, to not let the tears sting her eyes. Melissa puts her hands on top of hers, to try to ground her out of her emotions. “We did the best we could. //You// did the best you could. You helped those left to find a safe place to live. You made sure they never went more than a day without needing what they needed the most. Don’t you remember any of that?” Amelie takes a deep breath. “Yeah, you’re right. But I don’t know if that compares to what we lost. What I lost.” “You can’t change the past, Amy. All we can do now is carry on and honor them and what they stood for.” Amelie chuckles at how ironic that is. “As if what they stood for isn’t dead. I killed it, Mel. I should’ve talked to them more, I should’ve been there for them, but you want to know what I did? I kept worrying about spreadsheets and expense reports.” She stands up to make her point, gesticulating like a passionate lecturer. “Maybe this is anomalous hibernation, or something. They’re all asleep, and they’ll come back one day when the world isn’t a graveyard where dreams go to die. Nothing about what happened makes any goddamn sense at all. Sure, every anomaly got up and went to the farm upstate at the exact same time! That makes perfect sense! Don’t you think that’s anomalous in and of itself? Don’t you think we could’ve done something about that? We could’ve gotten a team, and I would’ve been on that team, and it wouldn’t matter how much sleep I would lose cause I would’ve done it for—” Melissa grabs her by the shoulder, gesturing to her to sit down. “Hey. You’re going to make a scene. Deep breaths, okay?” Breathe in, breathe out. Amelie sits down, ignoring the people that are probably staring at her by now, and looks down at her food for a while, unwilling to even gather the strength to touch it with her fork. It’s always the question of when. When can she move on from something like this? When can she wake up one day and say that she’s now happy and fulfilled in life? Can she ever be happy anymore? She’s done the best she can to honor their memory and look forward to the future. But is that future possible without them? Is that possible without the magic of this world that made life worth living? Can there ever be a better future for her or the people that she cared for again? Melissa watches her with a look of pity. At least, that’s what it looks like to Amelie, who deserves all the judgement given to her. “I know how hard it is for you right now. It’s hard for me too, but we can’t keep fretting about what we could’ve done. That won’t change the fact that they’re gone. But we can still try to make things better for the people around us. You’ve done so much for so many people, Amy.” Amelie finally lets the floodgates through and sobs, freeing herself from all the pain that she repressed inside. “I’m sorry Mel, I’m so sorry…” The silence that unfolds is unbearable, but it’s better than burdening herself with something that she can’t control. She wipes the tears from her eyes. “I think I need help. With everything, really. I don’t know what to do.” “I’ll help you find what you need. You shouldn’t have to bear through this alone.” “I could’ve fixed things with Kirby, but now I lost what we had too. They looked up to me, you know? And then I just pushed them away,” Amelie admits. “I don’t think what you did is irreconcilable. It will take time, but they’ll forgive you one day. I know they will,” Melissa promises to her. “Do you think that they can come back one day? So this can all be over? I //need// this to be over.” The next thing she speaks to her is the most honest thing that she can say. “I don’t know, Amy. I really don’t. But we have each other, and that’s good enough for me.” The rest of their lunch passes in silence, before Melissa hurries to get to her next appointment. She gives a quick apology before rushing out the door. Amelie doesn’t move from her position. She contemplates everything that happened, everything that she’s seen. The children, with so much joy in their hearts and so much love to give, now gone with the wind. The bond that she and the other Caretakers had that’s as strong as a towering oak in a storm, now fallen apart at the seams. Moses Feghoot and his eyes that stare into her soul. There is no scenario that she can think of where she can move on. Not like this. It’s unfathomable. The tears return, and Amelie lets them wash her sorrows away. She won’t let the memories that she has of them all ever fade. Their names will be remembered and cherished for as long as she lives. As she ponders her position in the world and how she can make her work matter, the flowers bloom, the birds are chirping, and there are children who are laughing and making people’s days brighter. She may not know it, but there is still joy hiding beneath the floorboards of these ever-stagnating times. And the world carries on without her. the-wheel.raw_content:
One must imagine Sisyphus lucky.

Written by TheChunk

▸ More by this Author ◂

{$comments2}

F.A.Q.

{$doesthisfixthebug}

It’s not just gambling, we say. It’s entertainment. Our guests–never “customers,” always “guests”–don’t come here to make money. They come for the experience. They come for the ambiance. They come for the magic.

But our business can’t be entertainment, because the entertainment is free. The drinks are free. The shows are free. Bet enough and the rooms are free. Come back enough times and we’ll send a showgirl to your room with a bottle of Dom Perignon that you can drink out of her shoe. Go ahead. It’s complimentary.

The only thing that isn’t free are the bets. And yes, everyone bets. They bet enough to cover every cocktail, concert, executive suite and shoeful of Dom Perignon under this roof. And then after that, they leave enough on the table for this place to turn a profit.

Maybe there really is an experience. Maybe people play poker because they like the strategy. Maybe people play slot machines because they get giddy for flashing lights. Maybe people play blackjack because they’re better at math than making friends.

But roulette? Roulette is for people who like gambling. If there’s no money on the line, there is no game. If there’s no money on the line, the wheel doesn’t spin. But there’s always money. So the wheel never stops.

I’m not here to get rich. I’m not here to build a career. I’m here to do a job. People come to my table by the dozens to place their bets, watch the wheel, and have a good time. But I’ve given out all the good times I have left: the magic is spent, but the bets keep on coming. The well has run dry, but the wheel keeps on spinning.

I don’t run the show. I don’t keep the money. I just spin the wheel. But if the next ball lands on black, tonight is the night I walk away.

Spin?
Better luck next time!

Red.

The money keeps coming. The wheel spins again.

“If you win, you have to bet again,” I say. “At that point, it’s basically free.”

“If you lose, you have to bet again,” I say. “Otherwise, you’ll be down forever.”

It doesn’t matter what I say; they’ll always bet again. If they didn’t want to bet, they wouldn’t be in a casino. My job isn’t to change their mind. My job is to spin the wheel, count the money, and pretend to believe that under their tailored suits and overpriced aftershave there’s a human being who deserves to be acknowledged.

“This is my last bet,” Steve says. That’s what Steve always says. When he’s up $100, that’s what he says. When he’s down $100,000, that’s what he says. He knows I can’t stop him. He knows he can’t stop him either. So neither of us tries.

I almost felt something the first time he cried. I can’t say I felt bad, but I almost felt something. $500,000 is a lot to lose in one night. But if someone has $500,000 to lose, how much can they really need it? Steve could lose everything he’s ever owned, and his bank account would look exactly the same as mine. But you don’t see me crying, do you?

There was a time when I could do the song and dance and mean it, handing out smiles and quips and goodwill to every new face at my table as though they cost me nothing. The crowd seemed more full then, the people more varied, from newlyweds on their honeymoons to retirees making one last pit stop on the way to the grave. They paid a lot to come here, and left even more on the table. The least I could give them was a kind word.

But at the heart of it all, wherever they come from, however often they play, however much they bet, they’re all made from the same stuff. When there’s cash on the table, everyone is Steve. And a Steve without money is the worst kind of Steve. A Steve without money won’t even tip.

“This is my last bet,” Steve says, adding twice my monthly paycheck to the table.

If the ball lands on red, I will never see Steve again. I will walk away forever, with empty hands, empty pockets, and an empty bank account, and I will not cry about it.

Spin?
Thank you for playing!

Black.

It doesn’t matter what I say. They’ll always bet again.

No one smokes anymore. There was a time when every corner of the building was covered in decades of smoke: thousands of layers of residue lingered in the carpets and the drapes that were brown, but had not always been brown. We had petitioned the Commission to ban smoking in 2017. Then again in 2019. And 2021, and 2022. It was a workplace hazard, we said. Think of our health, we said. But no one who works here really cares for their health. We just wanted to get away from the smell.

The Commission relented in 2024. Smoking was banned, the air was cleared. We could breathe again. After a few smokeless nights we could breathe deeply enough to gag on our pride and choke on our hubris.

No single person thinks they smell. Maybe no single person does. But put a thousand men together in a room overnight, with steady drinks and soft lights, and there’s no way to escape the warm aroma of humanity. With no smoke to blot it out, the sweat of a thousand wagers mingles in an orgy of desperation, and settles on every piece of faded cloth and worn leather. After enough nights it infests every shred of clothing and every fiber of hair. It does not come out. Not even with bleach.

If this ball lands on red, I will never smell this vest and tie again.

Spin?
Time and chance happen to us all!

Black.

It’s time to try ammonia.

Enrique has cornered me in the bathroom. He is eager to show me his new tie. I am eager to pee. I cannot pee with him watching as he stands beside me at the urinal, but he will watch until I finish. We are locked in an impasse, and I have three minutes until my shift resumes.

“This tie. It costs $500.” He holds up an unassuming black and red tie, a gift from one of his dozens of admirers. Buses of dowagers ride in every month to spend away their fortunes by the fistful. The chance to give gifts to Enrique is one of the many perks that keep them coming back. I strain until my face turns red, but nothing comes out.

“But this tie?” Enrique holds out the red and black tie around his neck and flicks it in my face. “This costs $1000.”

I strain until I feel something pop. If it comes out red, I will walk out of this bathroom, out of the building, and I will never return. I will not zip my pants. I will not wash my hands.

Spin?
Been down so long it looks like up to me!

Black.

I have two minutes until my shift resumes.

Most men at my table come alone. Some bring their buddies. A few bring their wives. A few bring their hookers.

The hourly rate for a halfway respectable hooker starts at $300. $300 per hour is a lot to pay a woman to blow on your dice, fondle your chips, and rub your bald head for good luck between complimentary drinks. But these same men throw away $300 to watch a wheel spin for 30 seconds, then throw $600 after it just to make sure. Maybe for them, $300 per hour is a bargain.

I used to think that only a special kind of fool would pay to lose money. Now I know that no one in this place is special.

“You don’t pay them to fuck you,” he says, spilling his watered down Jack and Coke on my table. “You pay them to leave when you’re done!”

He laughs, as though he was the first man to say this to me tonight. I make eye contact with his busty companion, hoping his words don’t sting too much for her. For a minute, I sense she may be a kindred spirit: another soul like mine, putting up with the same customers night after night. It might not be glamorous, but it’s a living.

She shoots me a withering glance, as though to scold my eyes for seeing her, then smiles at her client, and begins to rub his bald head for good luck. I consider, for a moment, how much she makes in a year. Maybe we’re not so kindred after all.

If this ball lands on black, I will make nothing next year, and I will have earned every penny.

Spin?
Probability is a social construct!

Red.

At least I get paid to lose.

Cocaine is not allowed here. Cocaine is a drug. Cocaine is illegal. This is a legitimate entertainment venue, not a den of vice.

But cocaine is the enemy of sleep. And sleep is the enemy of gambling. So if someone wants to gamble all night, technically I can’t stop them.

If they want to go to the bathroom and do a line off the toilet seat, I can’t stop them. If they want to go to the bathroom and do a line off Enrique’s dick, I can’t stop them. If they want to drop an 8-ball on my table and do bumps off their chips all night, I can’t stop them.

I can’t stop them, but I can’t join them.

If the ball lands on red, I will never see Enrique’s dick again, and I will not miss it.

Spin?
Meet me halfway: buy a ticket!

Black.

I will work all night, and no one can stop me.

I have played this game a thousand times. Spin the wheel. Guess the color. Get it right and I’m gone forever.

There are no windows or clocks. There is no day and no night. There is a wheel and a wager, and nothing for miles beyond the clatter of coins and the hum of idle gadabouts.

I have played this game a thousand times, but man versus fate is not a fair fight.

There are sweat stains in my collar. There are bloodstains in my shoes. There is an itch I cannot scratch, not because I cannot reach it, but because I cannot remember where it is. My ears ring, but all sounds drown out one another in a cacophony of desperation.

Somewhere at the bar, a businessman pays his tab for the last time. He will never return home, and I will not miss him.

Somewhere behind a locked door, armed guards load a dump truck full of money that I will never get to see.

One more spin, and the game is over. Red or black, it doesn’t matter: I choose both. Whichever it is, when the ball stops, the bets will end, the world will be silent, and I will sleep at last.

Spin.
Hide.

Double Zero.

The bets keep coming. So the wheel never stops.

    The Wheel (Is Turning Now)
    Author: TealQuacks
    The day ended with Nathan Valis standing at the rock bottom of Sloths Pit, staring up at the forest around it. Birds sang back and forth to one another, none the wiser to the end of the world.

On the day magic died, he awoke with a name he lost long ago. It felt unfamiliar on his tongue. Its sound bounced around his mind in strange angles. Looking in the mirror, at his sharpened jaw and deflated curls, only confirmed the impossible.

Nathan Valis stared at the image in the glass, at the face the world had scrubbed from its memory.

He scarcely had time to look into his eyes before his phone started to light up with messages. They were turning to him for answers, like he would know how this happened, how to fix the death of magic.

There was nothing that could be done.

The day ended with Nathan Valis standing at the rock bottom of Sloths Pit, staring up at the forest around it. Birds sang back and forth to one another, none the wiser to the end of the world. Nathan stared up at the slate grey sky as if it would answer his questions, as if he’d be able to glimpse past the clouds and see the empty space where the authors used to be, before they’d up and left.

No, he reasoned, the authors hadn’t abandoned them. They’d simply wrapped their impossible hands around the beating heart of the universe, and yanked.

Blood warm rain struck his head, but he didn’t move from the bottom of the bottomless pit, staring up from what should’ve been an abyss.

The only thing worse than the sudden death of every wonder of the world was the job market.

Nathan gnawed the filter of his cigarette as he slumped his way back home from his second job. The Foundation had crumbled like a house of cards, and while they did pay out a pension, with no anomalies to contain or pataphysics to study, he was out of a job. Most of the others at Site-87 had moved on, to different cities, to better jobs. Some went back to school, others found jobs at universities or corporations. He had found no such luck. Unfortunately, working for a shadow organization and focusing on highly anomalous sciences didn’t make for a great resume. Much of his research was rendered useless by the sudden disappearance of anomalies, and he’d been comfortably hidden behind the veil for so much of his life that he had no references or recent past experience. In the two years since magic disappeared, he had gotten nothing but rejections. He was stuck in Sloth’s Pit.

During the day he restocked shelves in Sloth Pit’s library, the only part of the town where stories still lived. It bored him to tears, so much so he picked up a job as a busboy in a restaurant thirty minutes outside of the town. Not glamorous by any means, but it kept him from feeling like a caged animal picking at its own fur. The staff were nice, at least, and didn’t mind his lack of history or his constant bumming of cigarettes. All he had to do was pick up dishes and polish silverware, over and over and over. Monotonous, menial.

His phone buzzed in his pocket, souring his mood further. Lillian had texted him that morning, asking how he was. He didn’t respond. That did nothing to stop her messages, phone buzzing every 30 minutes or so. Part of him wanted to see what she had to say, but it’d probably just be her talking about her doctorate program. Neurolinguistics. A fascinating field. His phone buzzed again. And again. He should've been happy for her, but all he felt was the suffocating crush of another day wasted putting away books and doing dishes. Dull, banal work. He swallowed down his bitterness.

He jaywalked across a pothole-studded street, then hops up onto the sidewalk. For Sale signs creaked softly in the breeze. Almost every other house had one in front of it, because every story in Sloths Pit had come to an abrupt end. No climax, no falling action, just the inescapable conclusion. And everyone was left with the same question: What comes next? What could they possibly do now that their lives had been altered forever, turned into something unrecognizable? It was a question Nathan had been forced to ask after his identity was abstracted, and it was now being forced upon him again.

An engine's rumble pulled him out of his reverie. Cigarette smoke clouded his vision, but through it he could see a red sports car rolling slowly down the street. Nathan froze, squinting at the vehicle while he took a long drag of his cigarette. It looked familiar, even though he knew he'd never seen that car in Sloths Pit before. But he'd seen it before, before he came to Site-87 and left his un-abstracted past behind. The car idled up to him, engine purring like a stalking cat. Slowly, the window rolled down. Nathan's eyes widened.

“I thought you quit smoking."

Nathan blinked, brain struggling to catch up.

“I thought you were in California,” he said, eyes fixed on the man behind the wheel.

Ryoto Hishakaku laughed. He shifted the car into park, and crossed his legs idly, seatbelt still tight over his chest. Black leather shoes gleamed with fresh polish, and he wore deep blue dress pants, a white button up, a deep blue suit jacket and vest. One hand rested on the wheel, and a shiny golden watch sparkled like frost on his wrist. Time hadn't completely spared him, though, as Nathan took in the new wrinkles around his eyes and mouth. They made him look wise, even though Nathan knew very well that that was far from the case. Ryoto grinned casually.

“Am I not allowed to visit an old friend?”

Nathan’s brows furrowed. Friends? How rich. It was over a decade since they'd spoken, even longer since the two had a conversation that wasn't just professional courtesies. The last time had to be just before he was abstracted, since after he turned into Placeholder McDoctorate any fondness the other man had towards him had vanished. Ryoto turned cold, grew distant, even though he was still his assistant director. It didn't take him long to decide to leave Site-15, stepping down from his position as director. The memory of Ryoto's bared teeth and furrowed brows was as clear as day, demanding to know why Barker had been made director instead of him. All he could do was stutter helplessly, still reeling from having his identity burnt to the ground.

Now, after everything, Ryoto had the audacity to call him his friend.

“That was a very long time ago, Ryoto," Nathan said.

“Things have changed since then, haven't they?"

Nathan's lip twitched.

“Yeah. You’ve gotten older.”

Ryoto smirked, as smarmy as Nathan remembered him.

“It’s good to see you too.”

His smile was too calm, too sweet. It looked wrong on his face in a way that made Nathan's lip twitch. Ryoto’s smile faded. Without the lines around his eyes, he looked like he did when they first met. Young, full of unbridled ambition and potential waiting to be harnessed. Something ugly stirred in Nathan’s chest, staring at the face of the man before him.

“Why are you here?” He snapped. “Are you trying to gloat, or something?”

“I just wanted to ask if you’d like to get dinner with me,” Ryoto said.

Nathan would have been less shocked if someone had thrown a bag over his head and beaten him with a saxophone. He raised his brows incredulously.

“Dinner? With you?”

“It’s been a while since we’ve talked.”

Nathan scoffed.

“I think you forget the terms we parted on.”

Nathan glared icily at Ryoto. The other man didn’t seem affected at all, just staring at him like he was trying to memorize every inch of his face. Maybe he was. Abstraction had altered him physically as well as mentally, some incomprehensible force shaping him like wet clay into a vessel for the narrative. Tabula rasa.

Ryoto stared at him in silence. He pursed his lips together.

"What?" Nathan snapped. Ryoto blinked, pulled out of his thoughts.

“I thought you died that day.”

Nathan scoffed. “That is a gross oversimplification."

“I’m sure it is.” Ryoto sighed. “I've read SCP-5242 over and over, and I still don't fully grasp what Integer did to you when you spoke that things name. It's like you died."

Nathan winced at the monochrome of his words. He stared down at the sidewalk, but even then he could see Ryoto’s car wheels edged up against the curb.

“I didn't die. I was just abstracted.”

“But you weren't you anymore, were you?" Ryoto asked, uncomfortably earnest, "you weren't Nathan."

His jaw opened, then shut. As much as he wanted to snap that he was and had always been Nathan Valis, that just wasn’t true. It hadn't been true for a long time, even as he insisted his name was nothing but an anomalous prank, a place holder for his real name.

He sighed, pinching the bridge of his nose. Well. Free dinner was free dinner. It wasn't like he had anything better to do with his night.

“Are you paying, at least?”

Ryoto smirked.

“What else am I good for?”

Ryoto leaned over the center console and unlocked the passenger door. Without a second to question himself, Nathan opened the door, and slid into the plush leather passenger seat. The doors locked with a click as Nathan buckled his seatbelt. Soft purring lept into a roar as Ryoto shifted into drive, and took off down the street. Nathan grimaced at his speed. Ryoto just rolled his eyes at him.

“Don’t be like that, you won’t regret this.”

Nathan closed his eyes. The car smelled like fresh upholstery, mixed with Ryoto’s cologne. The scent brought back a memory, the two of them driving to a gas station by Site-15 when the coffee machine in the break room had broken. Then, Nathan had been a director, and Ryoto had been an overeager researcher who trailed him like a duckling. They drove while Ryoto rambled about future projects and future plans, eyes alight with an unstoppable ambition.

A month after that drive, Nathan would decide to promote Ryoto to his assistant director.

He had yet to fully decide if that had been a mistake.

Leaving Sloths Pit, the sky opened up and dumped rain down onto the dried out husks of cornfields that line the highway. Ryoto drummed his fingers on the wheel as he sped down the highway. Nathan crossed his hands over his chest. The rain sapped all the heat from the air, but he didn’t dare mess with the complex controls. He used to feel compelled to press any button or switch he saw, a normal trait for any mad-scientist archetypical, but the urge never came. A small mercy, he supposed.

“Do you like it in Sloths Pit?” Ryoto asked. Nathan shifted in his seat.

“It’s fine," He said, but his voice was cold. Ryoto raised a brow at him, but quickly turned his gaze back to the endless road. Nathan tilted his head. Being director had aged Ryoto. There were faint bags under his eyes, hidden with skillfully applied makeup. His skin was smooth, but he could see faint marks on his cheek from when Ryoto was younger, when he’d get acne from stress that he’d pick at until it scarred. Ryoto glanced at him again.

“It must be peaceful now that there’s not, you know."

Nathan silently watched dark thunderheads as they crested the horizon. Boring, more like. The chaos, the stories, the endless mysteries of Sloths Pit was what made living there . Every day was a new adventure to charge headlong into, purple labcoat billowing behind him like a stormcloud.

“Everywhere’s fucking peaceful," he grumbled.

“Isn’t that nice,” Ryoto mused, “peace on earth."

He flicked the headlights on, illuminating the fall of every single drop. Nathan rubbed his own arms, suddenly chilled to the bone.

Peace on earth. Empty containment cells. Nexuses turned ghost towns, graveyards.

“Billions died, Ryoto.”

“That makes us very lucky then, doesn’t it?”

They drove on, past corn, corn, and more corn.

“I suppose it does.”

Ryoto parked in front of a modern building surrounded by hydrangea bushes, glass windows smeared with rain like an impressionist painting. Just from looking at the restaurant, Nathan knew he was underdressed in his coat, ratty t-shirt, and cargo pants.

Something poked him out of nowhere. He looked over, and Ryoto was offering him a black umbrella.

“…thanks,” he murmured.

He slid the door open, and quickly put up the umbrella. His sandals splashed in parking lot puddles as he ran to the restaurant door, quickly ducking inside. Ryoto was right on his heels, the two of them stumbling into the foyer. The restaurant was warmly lit, tables covered with white table cloths and a single candle. Ryoto spoke to the host, confirmed his reservation, and soon Nathan was following him through the restaurant, trying to ignore the stares of the well dressed patrons all around him. Even Ryoto in his rain-speckled suit looked classy, the darker spots slowly fading as they dry.

Someone was at their table already. A busboy with short brown curls, cleaning silverware with a white rag. Polishing with such single-minded focus, the boy didn’t notice the three of them lingering over his shoulder. Nathan could almost see himself in that seat, polishing enough forks for a royal dinner while guests waited to sit, a dark reflection of himself. The boy even had his curls. Nathan looked away as their host coughed, getting his attention. The busboy gathered his forks and knives, scurrying away as the host gave them their menus. They sat.

“Do you know what you want to eat?” Ryoto asked. Nathan shrugged, thumbing the edge of the menu.

“I haven’t thought much about it. You?”

Ryoto squinted at the menu for a few moments, then set it down.

“The scallops, I think. The pilaf that comes with it is to die for. Normally I’d have wine, but I think I’ll stick to water tonight. And you?”

Nathan ran his finger up and down his menu. A list of steaks caught his eye, and his stomach growled. He hadn’t had steak in a long, long time. One of the steaks was a sixty seven dollar dry aged ribeye. It would take almost an entire shift at the library to afford that steak. At least he wasn’t spending his own money. Anyone would know who was paying just by looking at them. Ryoto in his smart suit, him in his unwashed t shirt. He shifted awkwardly in his seat. Someone had written him into the wrong story.

“How’s 15?” Nathan asked, tapping his foot against expensive carpet. Ryoto shrugged.

“Same old same old. Still salvaging what we can, still trying to keep it pushing. And 87?”

Nathan glanced out the window.

“Defunct. We lost all funding.”

Ryoto’s brows pinched together, sympathetic. Flickering candlelight made his expression look softer. Now that he was closer, Nathan noticed flecks of silver starting at the man’s temples.

“I’m so sorry to hear that.”

“I bet you are. So sorry." Nathan scoffed. “Where was this version of you when I needed it?”

Ryoto’s face didn’t change. He still looked sympathetic. Pitying.

“I was terrified,” he continued, “I was so alone, so goddamn scared.”

“So was I.”

"The entire site alienated me. You did too. Even when we knew how Integer worked, you avoided me like I was contagious, like I had a disease."

Ryoto looked away, out the window at the flowers being battered by the rain. His lips pinched together in a tight line. Nathan waited for the other man to say something, to offer up an explanation or an apology, but he simply stayed silent.

The waiter approached, a metal pitcher dripping condensation in his hand.

“Do you gentlemen know what you’re ordering?”

“Yes,” Ryoto said, both hands flat on his menu, “I’ll be having the scallops, and my friend will have the New York strip, medium rare.”

With an air of finality, Ryoto passed his menu to the waiter, who skittered away after filling their cups with frigid water. Nathan stared at him, expression blank. Ice clinked around in the crystal glass.

"It's been years, Ryoto," Nathan said, "I want to know why you avoided me, why you treated me like some sort of monster. Did I do something? Because if I did, I don't remember. I was nothing but good to you, even when you really, really didn't deserve it."

"That's true."

"So what was your problem?"

Ryoto sighed. "I thought you were dead."

Nathan nearly laughed in disbelief.

"What?"

"I thought that you’d been murdered, and… something was walking around in your skin."

Nathan's lip curled in frustration and disgust. Ryoto didn't look at him, just fiddled with his cufflinks while staring at the carpet.

"That's not how abstraction works, Ryoto. I was still me."

"It didn't feel like that."

"And how did you think it felt being ignored by my assistant director during the worst time of my fucking life?"

"How did you think it felt to search everywhere I could for your name just to find it replaced with "Placeholder McDoctorate", even in my journals? How did you think it felt to go into work every day, and look at your face knowing it was wrong, but not knowing how!?"

"Probably as shitty as it felt to see that face in the mirror every day," Nathan snarled.

"It made you act different, too," Ryoto continued, "but I never could figure out how. And that terrified me. I couldn't handle it, so I stayed away. Every time I saw you it was just a horrible reminder of how I lost the one man in 15 that I respected. As far as I knew, the Nathan Valis I knew and cared about was gone for good.”

“You don't remember Nathan, nobody does."

"Yes, I do."

"I don’t even remember who Nathan was, and I was him, apparently! All I’ve ever been is Placeholder McDoctorate, and he’s fucking gone now.”

Nathan blinked, face red and hot and wet with tears he hated himself for shedding. If only he could crawl under the table and hide from the rest of the world.

“He’s gone,” he repeated, “he’s gone.”

The pattering of rain filled the silence between them. If he closed his eyes, he could imagine the two of them were in his office, pouring over papers after a busy day, a rare California rain drenching the earth. Ryoto picked at the buttons of his suit jacket. After a few moments of quiet, he spoke.

“Do you remember when I broke the coffee machine at 15? We were so desperate we went to the nearest gas station for, even though their coffee tasted like shit and hardly woke us. We got lost on the way back. Remember?”

Nathan furrowed his brows, distracted from his feelings.

“Wait, you broke the coffee machine?”

Ryoto rubbed the back of his neck with an awkward grin. “Percussive maintenance gone wrong.”

“You punched the coffee machine and it broke?”

“Well when you put it that way…”

Nathan shook his head.

“You little shit— and you didn’t tell me?”

“Because I knew you’d get mad.”

“I could’ve fixed it!”

“While exhausted?” Ryoto scoffed, “it was a shitty machine anyway.”

“I bought that machine with my own money!”

“See? I said you’d get mad!” He crowed, face the picture of smug satisfaction, “I knew you would back then, and you did right now. So that means you haven’t changed that much. And it means that we remember."

Nathan almost laughed at Ryoto’s fervent insistence. Almost. Nathan picked up his cup and took a long sip of water, watching Ryoto’s eyes as they followed his movements. Had he spent this entire time studying every detail, comparing them against memories? Ryoto had known him as Nathan and as Placeholder; who did he think he was more like? Which version of him did he see?

“I never knew you cared so much."

“…I should’ve tried harder to let you know,” Ryoto whispered. He looked back up at him, and for a moment Nathan could've sworn his eyes were wet with tears.

Nathan opened his mouth to respond, only for the waiter to interrupt by setting their food in front of them. Ryoto’s plate was full of fluffy rice and scallops that looked like roasted marshmallows, and his own plate had a steak, with mashed potatoes and broccoli, piled high. Steam rose from both plates in wispy curls, filling the air with the aroma of cooked meat and well-seasoned vegtables.

“Holy shit,” Nathan said. Ryoto chuckled.

“See? I said you wouldn’t regret it.”

Nathan picked up his knife, running his thumb over the hilt. His reflection in the steak knife was smeared and warped.

“I don't think I do."

He sliced into the meat, and the two of them ate in silence. His steak was thick and rich, a little on the bloody side, but still delicious. The mashed potatoes were the real showstopper, still a bit chunky with bits of skin and lots of butter. Each scrape of his spoon against the plate made a hideous screech, but it was worth it to get every last bit.

“We should do this more often,” Ryoto mused, watching him lick the last bit of mashed potatoes on his spoon, pupils so blown his almond shaped eyes looked black instead of brown.

“That’d be a waste of jet fuel,” Nathan snorted, “flying 2,000 miles when you could just call.”

“It’d be easier if we lived closer together.”

“No offense, but you’re a city slicker through and through. You’d hate Sloths Pit.”

“That’s not what I had in mind.”

Nathan froze, looking up from his plate. Ryoto stared right back at him. He used to be able to read Ryoto like a book, but now the man’s expression was incredulous.

"I'm not going back to 15."

"That's not what I had in mind either."

The rain-smeared windows suddenly felt as claustrophobic as foot-thick concrete. Deep worry settled like a rock in his gut. If he was still Placeholder, he could’ve done something corny but narratively effective to get out of the situation, like tug at his collar with a cry of “check please?” Now that he was only Nathan Valis, he went with the only excuse he could think of.

“I need a cigarette,” Nathan declared.

Instead of protesting like he expected, Ryoto reached into his jacket and pulled out a golden lighter, offering it to him with an outstretched hand. Nathan had his own lighter, a white BIC that weighed heavily in his pocket as he stared at the golden metal glisten in the candlelight. Outside the rain still poured. All around them, busboys collected dishes into black bins, darting from table to table like flies.

“I’ll be out after I pay. Enjoy your smoke.”

The temptation to ask Ryoto what the hell he was talking about was nigh irresistible, but the thought of getting to smoke in peace before the long drive home distracted him.

Their fingers brushed as Nathan took the lighter. Ryoto’s hand was warm and soft, well-manicured. He tried not to think about the feeling of his hand, or the strange smile on his face, as he marched outside.
