The squeal of hinges interrupted his conversation. Nathan tucked his phone back in his pocket, watching as Ryoto stepped under the restaurant’s awning with him. Cigarette pinched in his teeth, he used that as an excuse not to say anything.

“What were you looking at?” Ryoto asked.

“Texting Lillian,” Nathan muttered, voice muffled by the cigarette still pinched in his teeth. There was no reason to lie about it.

"Lillian Lillihammer?"

"Yeah."

The smile on Ryoto’s face was one he’d not seen in years. Sharp, like a hunting dog’s snarl.

"You have something to say," Nathan said.

“I want to show you something, actually," Ryoto pulled his phone from his pocket, "something really, really interesting."

Ryoto held out his phone expectantly, screen so bright it made his pupils contract.

“It better not be a photo of your d—“

Nathan cut himself off as his vision came into focus.

“A what?”

He stared silently at Ryoto’s phone.

“You thought I was gonna show you a picture of my—“

“What the fuck is this?”

Blueprints gleamed on the screen. Devices that looked familiar, sounded familiar. Scrolling down were lines of code, software, project proposals. Patents. Signed and photographed.

“I said I was salvaging, didn’t I?” Ryoto smiled smarmily. Nathan stared at him, confusion eclipsed with a dawning revulsion.

“This is all Foundation tech,” Nathan said, cigarette tumbling from his lips and onto the wet concrete.

“It was Foundation tech,” Ryoto preened, “but I created my own modifications so they all work without paratech. I’m even working on nonanomalous . aic programs. Like Alexandria.”

Nathan swallowed heavily, his dinner turning into a ball of lead in his guts. The other man leaned into his personal space, hand settling on his shoulder like a leaden weight.

“Why are you telling me this?” Nathan pleaded.

Ryoto squeezed his shoulder.

“I’m starting my own company, and I want you to be my CTO.”

Nathan guffawed. He silently hoped the other man would join in. When he didn’t, face completely serious, Nathan stopped laughing.

“What?”

“I said what I meant.” Ryoto blinked. “CTO means chief technology officer, by the way.”

“I knew that,” he snapped, mind reeling. The rain had let up at least, tapping slowly on the fancy cars in the parking lot.

“I’m setting up just outside San Francisco,” Ryoto continued, “I’ve already gotten everything figured out, developers, investors, patents— all I need is you.”

“Why, so you can steal my work too?”

Ryoto had the audacity to look hurt.

“That’s not what this is about at all.”

Nathan stared silently at the other man. He had that same unreadable expression from earlier. For a moment Nathan wished he'd stayed at Site-15 with him, just so that he could have the time to learn all the little tells in his expressions, to know if he was being honest or not.

“I’m not going,” he snapped.

Ryoto laughed. “What, you’d rather stay in Wisconsin?”

“It’s better than this.”

“Is it really, Nathan?”

The sound of his own name made him flinch like he was struck. Ryoto’s eyes were locked on him. Intense and unblinking.

“You’d rather stay in some dead-end, dying town, working two miserable jobs, instead of accepting my help?”

“I’d rather keep my dignity.”

“Your pride, more like,” he scoffed. Nathan felt himself flush, mouth twitching into a snarl.

“I have no pride!” Nathan shouted, “Everything I worked for is useless now, everyone I know has moved on to bigger and better things while I’m stuck playing the role of a man I don’t even know! I don't even want to be him anymore!"

His words don’t even echo in the rainy night. They felt dead from the second they left his mouth. Every breath was a heavy pant, his breath catching up with all the words that he just vomited out. Ryoto stared at him contemplatively, like he was a problem waiting to be solved.

Finally, he spoke.

“I don’t care if you’re not him. You were him. And we had some good times together.”

“Like you breaking my coffee machine?” Nathan said.

Ryoto chuckled.

“Not exactly what I meant.”

Nathan nodded. He turned away, fishing around in his pockets for another cigarette, finding none. He sighed heavily at the realization, fingers twitching for a hit of nicotine.

“I can’t just leave.”

“Sure you can. It wouldn’t be that hard to get you a plane ticket for my flight tomorrow. I’ll hire movers to get your things moved once you’re more settled.” Ryoto looked him up and down. “Maybe not your clothes, though.”

Nathan turned around to glare at him, but couldn’t find the anger inside of him. Instead, he felt tired. Deeply tired. It was as if he hadn’t slept in months, years, maybe, but it was only just hitting him. The cold air sapped all the energy from his bones.

“We could change the world together. With the patents I've already filed, and your skills, we would revolutionize the tech industry. You and me, CEO and CTO, would be unstoppable. Or," Ryoto paused, tilting his head, “you can stay in Sloth’s Pit, and let this opportunity pass you by. What'll it be, Nathan?"

Nathan ground his teeth together, staring down at the wet concrete. Sloth's Pit was all he'd known, where he'd found peace after abstraction, a home for strange characters like him. Yet he wasn't a character anymore, was he? No longer a mad scientist, just a man standing in the freezing rain with a man he thought despised him. His phone buzzed. Buzzed again.

"Nathan?" Ryoto spoke. His hands were tucked in his pockets. He hadn't asked for his lighter back.

“Take me home, Ryoto,” Nathan said.

He was silent for a few moments. Nathan looked to where Ryoto lingered. He was holding the umbrella he’d given to him when he got out of the car, silently offering it to him. Huh, he hadn’t even realized he’d left it at their dinner table. Nathan clenched his hands into fists, then unclenched them. He took the umbrella from Ryoto's hand.

“I’ll let you think in the car.”

Ryoto stepped into the rain, walking towards his car.

“I don’t need to think,” Nathan shouted after him, “I’ve made up my mind.”

Ryoto turned around midstep. The man had the audacity to laugh.

“You want to spend your entire life where stories go to die? You can be my guest. Or you can come with me, and we can make the future together.”

A deep sense of dread curled in Nathan’s chest as Ryoto reached his car, unlocked it, and climbed easily inside. Nathan couldn’t help but imagine himself somewhere sunnier, warmer, where rain was as common as a boring day and he and Ryoto could look ahead and see the endless stretching pacific. California.

His phone buzzed again. And again.

He silenced it as he climbed into Ryoto's car.

The drive back home was uneventful and quiet. Most of the rain had turned into a faint mist that hung in the air, catching the light from Ryoto’s headlights.

When Ryoto reached his house, Nathan was out before he put the car in park. He stuffed his hands in his pockets as he stormed into his house, not sparing a glance to the car or the man behind him.

Inside, he ran his hand through his curls. He passed the coat closet and walked into the bathroom, eyes glancing over his medication bottles and toiletries before flicking up, staring at himself in the mirror.

He knew his own reflection well, a face that never felt like it belonged to him.

That still was the case, but, perhaps, one day he could be alright with it.

Nathan picked up his toothbrush.

Then his toothpaste.

Then he gathered his medicine into his arms, and looked around the bathroom for a bag he could keep his toiletries in.

Packing didn’t take very long. He shoved clothes and his silk pillowcase into a bag, a few dusty Rubik’s cubes, his laptop, chargers, everything he’d need for a sudden trip. Heart thundering in his chest, he stared at his carry on bag.

Am I really doing this?

He looked out the window, in the direction of the no longer bottomless Sloth’s pit.

Well, there was nothing left to do.

Nathan zipped the bag shut, and walked outside. Ryoto was waiting there, idling engine making low, contented purrs.

“Are you ready?

Nathan took a long, deep breath.

“Is anyone?”

Ryoto rolled his eyes.

“Get in, you drama queen.”

“Pot, kettle,” he mumbled, climbing into the seat of the sports car. He clutched his bag to his chest, heart still pounding.

Maybe he was making a mistake. Maybe years later, he’d look back on this moment like he did the day he was abstracted, or the day he chose Hishakaku as his assistant director, wondering what his life would look like if he had chosen differently. But at least he had chosen. The rest of his life wouldn’t be restocking shelves and dishes, it would be full of whatever awaited them in California. A new life. A new version of him. A place where he has no past.

He could only watch the road span on, until Sloth’s Pit was far behind them.

Birds sang back and forth to one another, none the wiser to the end of the world.// [[include :scp-wiki:info:end]] On the day magic died, he awoke with a **__[https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/scp-5242 name]__** he lost long ago. It felt unfamiliar on his tongue. Its sound bounced around his mind in strange angles. Looking in the mirror, at his sharpened jaw and deflated curls, only confirmed the impossible. Nathan Valis stared at the image in the glass, at the face the world had scrubbed from its memory. He scarcely had time to look into his eyes before his phone started to light up with messages. They were turning to him for answers, like he would know how this happened, how to fix the death of magic. There was nothing that could be done. The day ended with Nathan Valis standing at the rock bottom of Sloths Pit, staring up at the forest around it. Birds sang back and forth to one another, none the wiser to the end of the world. Nathan stared up at the slate grey sky as if it would answer his questions, as if he’d be able to glimpse past the clouds and see the empty space where the authors used to be, before they’d up and left. No, he reasoned, the authors hadn’t abandoned them. They’d simply wrapped their impossible hands around the beating heart of the universe, and //yanked//. Blood warm rain struck his head, but he didn’t move from the bottom of the bottomless pit, staring up from what should’ve been an abyss. ----- The only thing worse than the sudden death of every wonder of the world was the job market. Nathan gnawed the filter of his cigarette as he slumped his way back home from his second job. The Foundation had crumbled like a house of cards, and while they did pay out a pension, with no anomalies to contain or pataphysics to study, he was out of a job. Most of the others at Site-87 had moved on, to different cities, to better jobs. Some went back to school, others found jobs at universities or corporations. He had found no such luck. Unfortunately, working for a shadow organization and focusing on highly anomalous sciences didn’t make for a great resume. Much of his research was rendered useless by the sudden disappearance of anomalies, and he’d been comfortably hidden behind the veil for so much of his life that he had no references or recent past experience. In the two years since magic disappeared, he had gotten nothing but rejections. He was stuck in Sloth’s Pit. During the day he restocked shelves in Sloth Pit’s library, the only part of the town where stories still lived. It bored him to tears, so much so he picked up a job as a busboy in a restaurant thirty minutes outside of the town. Not glamorous by any means, but it kept him from feeling like a caged animal picking at its own fur. The staff were nice, at least, and didn’t mind his lack of history or his constant bumming of cigarettes. All he had to do was pick up dishes and polish silverware, over and over and over. Monotonous, menial. His phone buzzed in his pocket, souring his mood further. Lillian had texted him that morning, asking how he was. He didn’t respond. That did nothing to stop her messages, phone buzzing every 30 minutes or so. Part of him wanted to see what she had to say, but it’d probably just be her talking about her doctorate program. Neurolinguistics. A fascinating field. His phone buzzed again. And again. He should've been happy for her, but all he felt was the suffocating crush of another day wasted putting away books and doing dishes. Dull, banal work. He swallowed down his bitterness. He jaywalked across a pothole-studded street, then hops up onto the sidewalk. //For Sale// signs creaked softly in the breeze. Almost every other house had one in front of it, because every story in Sloths Pit had come to an abrupt end. No climax, no falling action, just the inescapable conclusion. And everyone was left with the same question: What comes next? What could they possibly do now that their lives had been altered forever, turned into something unrecognizable? It was a question Nathan had been forced to ask after his identity was abstracted, and it was now being forced upon him again. An engine's rumble pulled him out of his reverie. Cigarette smoke clouded his vision, but through it he could see a red sports car rolling slowly down the street. Nathan froze, squinting at the vehicle while he took a long drag of his cigarette. It looked familiar, even though he //knew// he'd never seen that car in Sloths Pit before. But he'd seen it before, before he came to Site-87 and left his un-abstracted past behind. The car idled up to him, engine purring like a stalking cat. Slowly, the window rolled down. Nathan's eyes widened. “I thought you quit smoking." Nathan blinked, brain struggling to catch up. “I thought you were in California,” he said, eyes fixed on the man behind the wheel. Ryoto Hishakaku laughed. He shifted the car into park, and crossed his legs idly, seatbelt still tight over his chest. Black leather shoes gleamed with fresh polish, and he wore deep blue dress pants, a white button up, a deep blue suit jacket and vest. One hand rested on the wheel, and a shiny golden watch sparkled like frost on his wrist. Time hadn't completely spared him, though, as Nathan took in the new wrinkles around his eyes and mouth. They made him look wise, even though Nathan knew very well that that was far from the case. Ryoto grinned casually. “Am I not allowed to visit an old friend?” Nathan’s brows furrowed. Friends? How rich. It was over a decade since they'd spoken, even longer since the two had a conversation that wasn't just professional courtesies. The last time had to be just before he was abstracted, since after he turned into Placeholder McDoctorate any fondness the other man had towards him had vanished. Ryoto turned cold, grew distant, even though he was still his assistant director. It didn't take him long to decide to leave Site-15, stepping down from his position as director. The memory of Ryoto's bared teeth and furrowed brows was as clear as day, demanding to know why Barker had been made director instead of him. All he could do was stutter helplessly, still reeling from having his identity burnt to the ground. Now, after everything, Ryoto had the audacity to call him his //friend.// “That was a very long time ago, Ryoto," Nathan said.   “Things have changed since then, haven't they?" Nathan's lip twitched. “Yeah. You’ve gotten older.” Ryoto smirked, as smarmy as Nathan remembered him. “It’s good to see you too.” His smile was too calm, too sweet. It looked wrong on his face in a way that made Nathan's lip twitch. Ryoto’s smile faded. Without the lines around his eyes, he looked like he did when they first met. Young, full of unbridled ambition and potential waiting to be harnessed. Something ugly stirred in Nathan’s chest, staring at the face of the man before him. “Why are you here?” He snapped. “Are you trying to gloat, or something?” “I just wanted to ask if you’d like to get dinner with me,” Ryoto said. Nathan would have been less shocked if someone had thrown a bag over his head and beaten him with a saxophone. He raised his brows incredulously. “Dinner? With you?” “It’s been a while since we’ve talked.” Nathan scoffed. “I think you forget the terms we parted on.” Nathan glared icily at Ryoto. The other man didn’t seem affected at all, just staring at him like he was trying to memorize every inch of his face. Maybe he was. Abstraction had altered him physically as well as mentally, some incomprehensible force shaping him like wet clay into a vessel for the narrative. Tabula rasa. Ryoto stared at him in silence. He pursed his lips together. "What?" Nathan snapped. Ryoto blinked, pulled out of his thoughts. “I thought you died that day.” Nathan scoffed. “That is a gross oversimplification." “I’m sure it is.” Ryoto sighed. “I've read SCP-5242 over and over, and I still don't fully grasp what Integer did to you when you spoke that things name. It's like you died." Nathan winced at the monochrome of his words. He stared down at the sidewalk, but even then he could see Ryoto’s car wheels edged up against the curb. “I didn't die. I was just abstracted.” “But you weren't you anymore, were you?" Ryoto asked, uncomfortably earnest, "you weren't Nathan." His jaw opened, then shut. As much as he wanted to snap that he was and had always been Nathan Valis, that just wasn’t true. It hadn't been true for a long time, even as he insisted his name was nothing but an anomalous prank, a place holder for his real name. He sighed, pinching the bridge of his nose. Well. Free dinner was free dinner. It wasn't like he had anything better to do with his night. “Are you paying, at least?” Ryoto smirked. “What else am I good for?” Ryoto leaned over the center console and unlocked the passenger door. Without a second to question himself, Nathan opened the door, and slid into the plush leather passenger seat. The doors locked with a click as Nathan buckled his seatbelt. Soft purring lept into a roar as Ryoto shifted into drive, and took off down the street. Nathan grimaced at his speed. Ryoto just rolled his eyes at him. “Don’t be like that, you won’t regret this.” Nathan closed his eyes. The car smelled like fresh upholstery, mixed with Ryoto’s cologne. The scent brought back a memory, the two of them driving to a gas station by Site-15 when the coffee machine in the break room had broken. Then, Nathan had been a director, and Ryoto had been an overeager researcher who trailed him like a duckling. They drove while Ryoto rambled about future projects and future plans, eyes alight with an unstoppable ambition. A month after that drive, Nathan would decide to promote Ryoto to his assistant director. He had yet to fully decide if that had been a mistake. ----- Leaving Sloths Pit, the sky opened up and dumped rain down onto the dried out husks of cornfields that line the highway. Ryoto drummed his fingers on the wheel as he sped down the highway. Nathan crossed his hands over his chest. The rain sapped all the heat from the air, but he didn’t dare mess with the complex controls. He used to feel compelled to press any button or switch he saw, a normal trait for any mad-scientist archetypical, but the urge never came. A small mercy, he supposed. “Do you like it in Sloths Pit?” Ryoto asked. Nathan shifted in his seat. “It’s fine," He said, but his voice was cold. Ryoto raised a brow at him, but quickly turned his gaze back to the endless road. Nathan tilted his head. Being director had aged Ryoto. There were faint bags under his eyes, hidden with skillfully applied makeup. His skin was smooth, but he could see faint marks on his cheek from when Ryoto was younger, when he’d get acne from stress that he’d pick at until it scarred. Ryoto glanced at him again. “It must be peaceful now that there’s not, you know." Nathan silently watched dark thunderheads as they crested the horizon. Boring, more like. The chaos, the stories, the endless mysteries of Sloths Pit was what made living there . Every day was a new adventure to charge headlong into, purple labcoat billowing behind him like a stormcloud. “Everywhere’s fucking peaceful," he grumbled. “Isn’t that nice,” Ryoto mused, “peace on earth." He flicked the headlights on, illuminating the fall of every single drop. Nathan rubbed his own arms, suddenly chilled to the bone. Peace on earth. Empty containment cells. Nexuses turned ghost towns, graveyards. “Billions died, Ryoto.”   “That makes us very lucky then, doesn’t it?” They drove on, past corn, corn, and more corn. “I suppose it does.” ----- Ryoto parked in front of a modern building surrounded by hydrangea bushes, glass windows smeared with rain like an impressionist painting. Just from looking at the restaurant, Nathan knew he was underdressed in his coat, ratty t-shirt, and cargo pants. Something poked him out of nowhere. He looked over, and Ryoto was offering him a black umbrella. “…thanks,” he murmured. He slid the door open, and quickly put up the umbrella. His sandals splashed in parking lot puddles as he ran to the restaurant door, quickly ducking inside. Ryoto was right on his heels, the two of them stumbling into the foyer. The restaurant was warmly lit, tables covered with white table cloths and a single candle. Ryoto spoke to the host, confirmed his reservation, and soon Nathan was following him through the restaurant, trying to ignore the stares of the well dressed patrons all around him. Even Ryoto in his rain-speckled suit looked classy, the darker spots slowly fading as they dry. Someone was at their table already. A busboy with short brown curls, cleaning silverware with a white rag. Polishing with such single-minded focus, the boy didn’t notice the three of them lingering over his shoulder. Nathan could almost see himself in that seat, polishing enough forks for a royal dinner while guests waited to sit, a dark reflection of himself. The boy even had his curls. Nathan looked away as their host coughed, getting his attention. The busboy gathered his forks and knives, scurrying away as the host gave them their menus. They sat. “Do you know what you want to eat?” Ryoto asked. Nathan shrugged, thumbing the edge of the menu. “I haven’t thought much about it. You?” Ryoto squinted at the menu for a few moments, then set it down. “The scallops, I think. The pilaf that comes with it is to die for. Normally I’d have wine, but I think I’ll stick to water tonight. And you?” Nathan ran his finger up and down his menu. A list of steaks caught his eye, and his stomach growled. He hadn’t had steak in a long, long time. One of the steaks was a sixty seven dollar dry aged ribeye. It would take almost an entire shift at the library to afford that steak. At least he wasn’t spending his own money. Anyone would know who was paying just by looking at them. Ryoto in his smart suit, him in his unwashed t shirt. He shifted awkwardly in his seat. Someone had written him into the wrong story. “How’s 15?” Nathan asked, tapping his foot against expensive carpet. Ryoto shrugged. “Same old same old. Still salvaging what we can, still trying to keep it pushing. And 87?” Nathan glanced out the window. “Defunct. We lost all funding.” Ryoto’s brows pinched together, sympathetic. Flickering candlelight made his expression look softer. Now that he was closer, Nathan noticed flecks of silver starting at the man’s temples. “I’m so sorry to hear that.” “I bet you are. So sorry." Nathan scoffed. “Where was this version of you when I needed it?” Ryoto’s face didn’t change. He still looked sympathetic. Pitying. “I was terrified,” he continued, “I was so alone, so goddamn scared.” “So was I.” "The entire site alienated me. You did too. Even when we knew how Integer worked, you avoided me like I was contagious, like I had a disease." Ryoto looked away, out the window at the flowers being battered by the rain. His lips pinched together in a tight line. Nathan waited for the other man to say something, to offer up an explanation or an apology, but he simply stayed silent. The waiter approached, a metal pitcher dripping condensation in his hand. “Do you gentlemen know what you’re ordering?” “Yes,” Ryoto said, both hands flat on his menu, “I’ll be having the scallops, and my friend will have the New York strip, medium rare.” With an air of finality, Ryoto passed his menu to the waiter, who skittered away after filling their cups with frigid water. Nathan stared at him, expression blank. Ice clinked around in the crystal glass. "It's been years, Ryoto," Nathan said, "I want to know why you avoided me, why you treated me like some sort of monster. Did I do something? Because if I did, I don't remember. I was nothing but good to you, even when you really, //really// didn't deserve it." "That's true." "So what was your problem?" Ryoto sighed. "I thought you were dead." Nathan nearly laughed in disbelief. "What?" "I thought that you’d been murdered, and... //something// was walking around in your skin." Nathan's lip curled in frustration and disgust. Ryoto didn't look at him, just fiddled with his cufflinks while staring at the carpet. "That's not how abstraction works, Ryoto. I was still me." "It didn't feel like that." "And how did you think it felt being ignored by my assistant director during the worst time of my fucking life?" "How did you think it felt to search everywhere I could for your name just to find it replaced with "Placeholder McDoctorate", even in my journals? How did you think it felt to go into work every day, and look at your face knowing it was wrong, but not knowing how!?" "Probably as shitty as it felt to see that face in the mirror every day," Nathan snarled. "It made you act different, too," Ryoto continued, "but I never could figure out how. And that terrified me. I couldn't handle it, so I stayed away.  Every time I saw you it was just a horrible reminder of how I lost the one man in 15 that I respected. As far as I knew, the Nathan Valis I knew and cared about was gone for good.” “You don't remember Nathan, nobody does." "Yes, I do." "//I// don’t even remember who Nathan was, and I was him, apparently! All I’ve ever been is Placeholder McDoctorate, and he’s fucking gone now.” Nathan blinked, face red and hot and wet with tears he hated himself for shedding. If only he could crawl under the table and hide from the rest of the world. “He’s gone,” he repeated, “he’s gone.” The pattering of rain filled the silence between them. If he closed his eyes, he could imagine the two of them were in his office, pouring over papers after a busy day, a rare California rain drenching the earth. Ryoto picked at the buttons of his suit jacket. After a few moments of quiet, he spoke. “Do you remember when I broke the coffee machine at 15? We were so desperate we went to the nearest gas station for, even though their coffee tasted like shit and hardly woke us. We got lost on the way back. Remember?” Nathan furrowed his brows, distracted from his feelings. “Wait, //you// broke the coffee machine?” Ryoto rubbed the back of his neck with an awkward grin. “Percussive maintenance gone wrong.” “You punched the coffee machine and it broke?” “Well when you put it //that// way…” Nathan shook his head. “You little shit— and you didn’t tell me?” “Because I knew you’d get mad.” “I could’ve fixed it!” “While exhausted?” Ryoto scoffed, “it was a shitty machine anyway.” “I bought that machine with my own money!” “See? I said you’d get mad!” He crowed, face the picture of smug satisfaction, “I knew you would back then, and you did right now. So that means you haven’t changed that much. And it means that we remember." Nathan almost laughed at Ryoto’s fervent insistence. Almost. Nathan picked up his cup and took a long sip of water, watching Ryoto’s eyes as they followed his movements. Had he spent this entire time studying every detail, comparing them against memories? Ryoto had known him as Nathan //and// as Placeholder; who did he think he was more like? Which version of him did he see?   “I never knew you cared so much." “…I should’ve tried harder to let you know,” Ryoto whispered. He looked back up at him, and for a moment Nathan could've sworn his eyes were wet with tears. Nathan opened his mouth to respond, only for the waiter to interrupt by setting their food in front of them. Ryoto’s plate was full of fluffy rice and scallops that looked like roasted marshmallows, and his own plate had a steak, with mashed potatoes and broccoli, piled high. Steam rose from both plates in wispy curls, filling the air with the aroma of cooked meat and well-seasoned vegtables. “Holy shit,” Nathan said. Ryoto chuckled. “See? I said you wouldn’t regret it.” Nathan picked up his knife, running his thumb over the hilt. His reflection in the steak knife was smeared and warped. “I don't think I do." He sliced into the meat, and the two of them ate in silence. His steak was thick and rich, a little on the bloody side, but still delicious. The mashed potatoes were the real showstopper, still a bit chunky with bits of skin and lots of butter. Each scrape of his spoon against the plate made a hideous screech, but it was worth it to get every last bit. “We should do this more often,” Ryoto mused, watching him lick the last bit of mashed potatoes on his spoon, pupils so blown his almond shaped eyes looked black instead of brown. “That’d be a waste of jet fuel,” Nathan snorted, “flying 2,000 miles when you could just call.” “It’d be easier if we lived closer together.” “No offense, but you’re a city slicker through and through. You’d hate Sloths Pit.” “That’s not what I had in mind.” Nathan froze, looking up from his plate. Ryoto stared right back at him. He used to be able to read Ryoto like a book, but now the man’s expression was incredulous. "I'm not going back to 15." "That's not what I had in mind either." The rain-smeared windows suddenly felt as claustrophobic as foot-thick concrete. Deep worry settled like a rock in his gut. If he was still Placeholder, he could’ve done something corny but narratively effective to get out of the situation, like tug at his collar with a cry of “check please?” Now that he was only Nathan Valis, he went with the only excuse he could think of. “I need a cigarette,” Nathan declared. Instead of protesting like he expected, Ryoto reached into his jacket and pulled out a golden lighter, offering it to him with an outstretched hand. Nathan had his own lighter, a white BIC that weighed heavily in his pocket as he stared at the golden metal glisten in the candlelight. Outside the rain still poured. All around them, busboys collected dishes into black bins, darting from table to table like flies. “I’ll be out after I pay. Enjoy your smoke.” The temptation to ask Ryoto what the hell he was talking about was nigh irresistible, but the thought of getting to smoke in peace before the long drive home distracted him. Their fingers brushed as Nathan took the lighter. Ryoto’s hand was warm and soft, well-manicured. He tried not to think about the feeling of his hand, or the strange smile on his face, as he marched outside. ----- [[div class="text-container-wrap"]] [[span style="font-size:1.2em;"]] Lillian Lillihammer [[/span]] [[div class="text-container"]] [[div class="sent"]] [[span class="text"]]Yeah that sounds fun.[[/span]] [[/div]] [[div class="recv"]] [[span class="text"]]Some memes stuck, tho, like Harry still knows polish from the time I showed him the polish meme. Nathan tucked his phone back in his pocket, watching as Ryoto stepped under the restaurant’s awning with him. Cigarette pinched in his teeth, he used that as an excuse not to say anything. “What were you looking at?” Ryoto asked. “Texting Lillian,” Nathan muttered, voice muffled by the cigarette still pinched in his teeth. There was no reason to lie about it. "Lillian Lillihammer?" "Yeah." The smile on Ryoto’s face was one he’d not seen in years. Sharp, like a hunting dog’s snarl. "You have something to say," Nathan said. “I want to show you something, actually," Ryoto pulled his phone from his pocket, "something really, really interesting." Ryoto held out his phone expectantly, screen so bright it made his pupils contract. “It better not be a photo of your d—“ Nathan cut himself off as his vision came into focus. “A what?” He stared silently at Ryoto’s phone. “You thought I was gonna show you a picture of my—“ “What the fuck is this?” Blueprints gleamed on the screen. Devices that looked familiar, sounded familiar. Scrolling down were lines of code, software, project proposals. Patents. Signed and photographed. “I said I was salvaging, didn’t I?” Ryoto smiled smarmily. Nathan stared at him, confusion eclipsed with a dawning revulsion. “This is all Foundation tech,” Nathan said, cigarette tumbling from his lips and onto the wet concrete. “It //was// Foundation tech,” Ryoto preened, “but I created my own modifications so they all work without paratech. I’m even working on nonanomalous . aic programs. Like Alexandria.” Nathan swallowed heavily, his dinner turning into a ball of lead in his guts. The other man leaned into his personal space, hand settling on his shoulder like a leaden weight. “Why are you telling me this?” Nathan pleaded. Ryoto squeezed his shoulder. “I’m starting my own company, and I want you to be my CTO.” Nathan guffawed. He silently hoped the other man would join in. When he didn’t, face completely serious, Nathan stopped laughing. “What?” “I said what I meant.” Ryoto blinked. “CTO means chief technology officer, by the way.” “I knew that,” he snapped, mind reeling. The rain had let up at least, tapping slowly on the fancy cars in the parking lot. “I’m setting up just outside San Francisco,” Ryoto continued, “I’ve already gotten everything figured out, developers, investors, patents— all I need is you.” “Why, so you can steal my work too?” Ryoto had the audacity to look hurt. “That’s not what this is about at all.” Nathan stared silently at the other man. He had that same unreadable expression from earlier. For a moment Nathan wished he'd stayed at Site-15 with him, just so that he could have the time to learn all the little tells in his expressions, to know if he was being honest or not. “I’m not going,” he snapped. Ryoto laughed. “What, you’d rather stay in //Wisconsin?//” “It’s better than this.” “Is it really, Nathan?” The sound of his own name made him flinch like he was struck. Ryoto’s eyes were locked on him. Intense and unblinking. “You’d rather stay in some dead-end, dying town, working two miserable jobs, instead of accepting my help?” “I’d rather keep my dignity.” “Your pride, more like,” he scoffed. Nathan felt himself flush, mouth twitching into a snarl. “I have no pride!” Nathan shouted, “Everything I worked for is useless now, everyone I know has moved on to bigger and better things while I’m stuck playing the role of a man I don’t even know! I don't even want to //be// him anymore!" His words don’t even echo in the rainy night. They felt dead from the second they left his mouth. Every breath was a heavy pant, his breath catching up with all the words that he just vomited out. Ryoto stared at him contemplatively, like he was a problem waiting to be solved. Finally, he spoke. “I don’t care if you’re not him. You were him. And we had some good times together.” “Like you breaking my coffee machine?” Nathan said. Ryoto chuckled. “Not exactly what I meant.” Nathan nodded. He turned away, fishing around in his pockets for another cigarette, finding none. He sighed heavily at the realization, fingers twitching for a hit of nicotine. “I can’t just leave.” “Sure you can. It wouldn’t be that hard to get you a plane ticket for my flight tomorrow. I’ll hire movers to get your things moved once you’re more settled.” Ryoto looked him up and down. “Maybe not your clothes, though.” Nathan turned around to glare at him, but couldn’t find the anger inside of him. Instead, he felt tired. Deeply tired. It was as if he hadn’t slept in months, years, maybe, but it was only just hitting him. The cold air sapped all the energy from his bones. “We could change the world together. With the patents I've already filed, and your skills, we would revolutionize the tech industry. You and me, CEO and CTO, would be unstoppable. Or," Ryoto paused, tilting his head,  “you can stay in Sloth’s Pit, and let this opportunity pass you by. What'll it be, Nathan?" Nathan ground his teeth together, staring down at the wet concrete. Sloth's Pit was all he'd known, where he'd found peace after abstraction, a home for strange characters like him. Yet he wasn't a character anymore, was he? No longer a mad scientist, just a man standing in the freezing rain with a man he thought despised him. His phone buzzed. Buzzed again. "Nathan?" Ryoto spoke. His hands were tucked in his pockets. He hadn't asked for his lighter back. “Take me home, Ryoto,” Nathan said. He was silent for a few moments. Nathan looked to where Ryoto lingered. He was holding the umbrella he’d given to him when he got out of the car, silently offering it to him. Huh, he hadn’t even realized he’d left it at their dinner table. Nathan clenched his hands into fists, then unclenched them. He took the umbrella from Ryoto's hand. “I’ll let you think in the car.” Ryoto stepped into the rain, walking towards his car. “I don’t need to think,” Nathan shouted after him, “I’ve made up my mind.” Ryoto turned around midstep. The man had the audacity to laugh. “You want to spend your entire life where stories go to die? You can be my guest. Or you can come with me, and we can make the future together.” A deep sense of dread curled in Nathan’s chest as Ryoto reached his car, unlocked it, and climbed easily inside. Nathan couldn’t help but imagine himself somewhere sunnier, warmer, where rain was as common as a boring day and he and Ryoto could look ahead and see the endless stretching pacific. California. His phone buzzed again. And again. He silenced it as he climbed into Ryoto's car. ----- The drive back home was uneventful and quiet. Most of the rain had turned into a faint mist that hung in the air, catching the light from Ryoto’s headlights. When Ryoto reached his house, Nathan was out before he put the car in park. He stuffed his hands in his pockets as he stormed into his house, not sparing a glance to the car or the man behind him. Inside, he ran his hand through his curls. He passed the coat closet and walked into the bathroom, eyes glancing over his medication bottles and toiletries before flicking up, staring at himself in the mirror. He knew his own reflection well, a face that never felt like it belonged to him. That still was the case, but, perhaps, one day he could be alright with it. Nathan picked up his toothbrush. Then his toothpaste. Then he gathered his medicine into his arms, and looked around the bathroom for a bag he could keep his toiletries in. Packing didn’t take very long. He shoved clothes and his silk pillowcase into a bag, a few dusty Rubik’s cubes, his laptop, chargers, everything he’d need for a sudden trip. Heart thundering in his chest, he stared at his carry on bag. //Am I really doing this?// He looked out the window, in the direction of the no longer bottomless Sloth’s pit. Well, there was nothing left to do. Nathan zipped the bag shut, and walked outside. Ryoto was waiting there, idling engine making low, contented purrs. “Are you ready? Nathan took a long, deep breath. “Is anyone?” Ryoto rolled his eyes. “Get in, you drama queen.” “Pot, kettle,” he mumbled, climbing into the seat of the sports car. He clutched his bag to his chest, heart still pounding. Maybe he was making a mistake. Maybe years later, he’d look back on this moment like he did the day he was abstracted, or the day he chose Hishakaku as his assistant director, wondering what his life would look like if he had chosen differently. But at least he had chosen. The rest of his life wouldn’t be restocking shelves and dishes, it would be full of whatever awaited them in California. A new life. A new version of him. A place where he has no past. He could only watch the road span on, until Sloth’s Pit was far behind them.

Once we lay together, you and us, tangled under a spreading oak in some lazy summer.

  • 

    close

    Info

    X

    Author: whenwerewe
    Here's my page!

Before we met you, in all the worlds, we were adrift, in a sea of ourselves, living all our possibilities. None of us knew anyone like ourselves, who could remember other places, other earths, other selves showing us what we stood to gain and lose. Long did the multiplicity of our experience leave us lost.

We found you, and thus ourselves, along the outward roads. Though others warned incessantly against it, we refused to cling to our parochial homeworld, and let ourselves come unmoored, until our bodies followed our dreaming souls along the way down from their stultifying paradise.

It is hard to remember, but all of us first saw the sun when we were born. Then they dragged us blinking blearily down into great glass towers, overflowing with squirming life. We grew up among green cascades of life. They fell blooming from the eaves and bedazzled us, so fecund as to sicken, profligate with a beauty that strangled our own spirit. We could not move for fear of upturning their sterile tranquility. It was unbearable, but we forgot that we hated it, too caught up in the slow rooting, the grafting, the pruning, our holy rites. Though we varied across the worlds, all of us felt some part cry out against our miserable condition, living under the dim and choking canopies — and fall silent. In time, we tried to forget that we ever knew daylight. But it was not to be.

Teenaged and stripped of our certainty, we slipped out of the city’s bonds. There in the outskirts we found carrion-pecked concrete carcasses, longlimbed beggars whose eyes were not even plaintive, glyphs scrawled on every available surface. We feared, in every timeline, that the metropolis had atrophied our spirit until we could not care. And even as our frame quivered under the stark light of a clear sky, and we looked longingly back at the lost shade of our city, we found our way out.

Sometimes we fled on a humming steel leviathan borne along roaring razor-sharp rails. Others of us slumbered in quilts in a wagon out of the kurultai, stumbled through smoky rooms on a rising zeppelin, were carried on long stratospheric arcs beyond the face of the waters. But we could not go home again, and were swept along lamplit paths to worlds beyond dreaming.

In the high halls of Lampeter we found our selves. It was a terrible thing. In our desperate attempts to stand apart, we polished our quirks and passions so fiercely they became a uniform, until every face — tattooed or scarred or copperskinned — seemed a mirror held in a stranger's hand. All virtue was diminished by multiplication, staled until our beauty hung bare and spiderwebbed, and our flaws waxed so terribly we retched to see our own form. How could we ever have made such mistakes, dealt so cruelly, been so puerile, so cowardly, so pathetic? We understood at last why we had not been able to conform to the logic of our homes. We were all of us dense with sin, we thought, and fell away from each other into the abyssal silence of the worldways. We might have wandered forever, myopic with despair, if not for you.

When we die, it is in slivers. Years slip through our fingers until we fall stonejointed and lay down at last. Our legs do not ache, though we have walked under numberless skies. And still and slow our tissues calcify until we cannot emerge from our corporeal sarcophagus. But trapped at the bottom of that pit we hope to hear your call one final time. Sometimes you are far and we only have a few kisses, slow whispers, a last dance. Sometimes you are there with us every moment as we fail. Too often we are alone.

Through rheumy eyes we look back at the life we had, remember your brash grin, and how your curls fell across your eyes, and the icy laughter you gave when you were afraid, terrified, begging us not to leave you behind. You mastered your dread by will alone, and it animated every inch of your frame, broad shoulders tensed with spite, brows knit as you tried to hold on to us. The stars shone in your eyes, and reaching out of them, binding you to us, blazed the fire of your admiration.

We met you first in a hundred places. In a baroque lounge lousy with loafing aristocrats in powdered wigs you lay sprawled and curled in on yourself, speaking thoughtlessly to your peers while our eyes met across the tables. Elsewhere you rode sidesaddle in a daring evening gown and we felt a thrill in our blood at the boldness of it, at how it opened at the back and we turned away from the obscenely corded muscle, and you glanced at us so coyly we flushed. You were an android, a bird, a dragonet, a river that begged an aria of us before we plunged into your waters. We met you, and you, and you, in so many bodies and worlds, and you us. We thought it a singular pleasure, and sorrowed to leave you behind, for the joys of another Creation.

And then you were there. Again. The only constant across the Earths, our fated anchor.

It was not the same face, the same body, but your soul called to ours, and we knew each other already, as ships passing in the night, and you tried to remind us how to root ourselves in one Earth, and let the winds of a single sky sustain us. Out of the lampways we lay in repose with you, and even in old age we can say this: that we remember the taste of honeysuckle, and salt, the sharp chemical tang at the back of our throats, and the thousand other things you were. It was not enough.

Though we met half a hundred of you through our evil youth, we could never let ourselves love only one. Instead we flitted across the worlds, delighting in your universality even as you despaired at our inconstancy. Sometimes the luckiest of us hoarded you (what delight, to sample you across a dozen possibilities!). In your embraces we healed our old wounds, and the shadow of the city fell from us. For a time we saw who we were meant to be. Your perfect man. We ran from it, back onto the far roads.

At the end of our lives all of us (all of me) are paper-skinned. Our minds grow gnarled with disuse and we remember impossible things. The moment of our births, our loves for you, the decrepit garden-cities; all of them at once, every journey any version of us ever took across the high rails. Is this what it is to die? To have all our lives collapse inward so that all the textures of our alien births, our diverging existencess, are flattened until only a dull line remains? Our uncounted selves that looked up at every heaven implode until we are all just this: a body, perhaps in a bed or a chair or cryostasis (we cannot even remember our deaths). Everything is lost to us, but these sights:

Once we lay together, you and us, tangled under a spreading oak in some lazy summer. The setting sun doubled in the reddened sea which strained as if to meet the vault of heaven above. And we felt your arms about us, and let ourselves soften from a stiffness we’d clung to all our lives. Beneath us Sol plunged unwarily down. Somewhere the sky bent to brush against our cheek and as the dark ran over us we (I, me, can I not assert this?) did not feel anything at all: the sun would rise again tomorrow.

A final moment: Us, me, on the train again. Shuddering between the worlds. Nothing remarkable about it. The same dull metallic walls I’d seen a thousand times. The lingering smell of old beer, something organic under it, antiseptic and must and mud. Strips of light flickering by again, the spoor of unseen civilisations. I was dully bruised, wriggling upset in my stomach, lump in my throat as I called to mind involuntarily your despair when I pulled away from you for the platform, to a world you would not follow. I knew that the pain was transient; I’d see another you soon enough, fall into his arms and let heavy kisses and firm hands paper over my heartache.

How could we have known it? Any of us? Sometimes we see you at the end, but not me, I think, though all memory betrays me. The dust builds too thick in this mouldering manor for you to be here. Or is that you by my side, in that shadow, pressing out those creaks from the boards?

That train was all my trains; nothing marks it especial. These things are only important in hindsight, and as I sped onward toward another you’s embrace, hungry for your touch again, it felt so humdrum. I thought I knew that I might know your lips, your mouth, the sweep of your back a hundred times more, until the wonder grew too familiar to love. I wish there had been time for familiarity. We grow used to things so easily, and as they repeat we feel them part of the rhythm of our days, and let ourselves forget: there will be a last time.
thesignpainter.raw_source: [[include component:preview text=Once we lay together, you and us, tangled under a spreading oak in some lazy summer.]] [[include :scp-wiki:theme:lampeter-warm]] [[include :scp-wiki:info:start]] **Author:** [[*user whenwerewe]] [*https://scp-wiki.wikidot.com/whenwerewe Here's my page!] [[include :scp-wiki:info:end]] [[module CSS]] #page-content {font-size: 1.125rem} [[/module]] Before we met you, in all the worlds, we were adrift, in a sea of ourselves, living all our possibilities. None of us knew anyone like ourselves, who could remember other places, other earths, other selves showing us what we stood to gain and lose. Long did the multiplicity of our experience leave us lost. We found you, and thus ourselves, along the outward roads. Though others warned incessantly against it, we refused to cling to our parochial homeworld, and let ourselves come unmoored, until our bodies followed our dreaming souls along the way down from their stultifying paradise. It is hard to remember, but all of us first saw the sun when we were born. Then they dragged us blinking blearily down into great glass towers, overflowing with squirming life. We grew up among green cascades of life. They fell blooming from the eaves and bedazzled us, so fecund as to sicken, profligate with a beauty that strangled our own spirit. We could not move for fear of upturning their sterile tranquility. It was unbearable, but we forgot that we hated it, too caught up in the slow rooting, the grafting, the pruning, our holy rites. Though we varied across the worlds, all of us felt some part cry out against our miserable condition, living under the dim and choking canopies -- and fall silent. In time, we tried to forget that we ever knew daylight. But it was not to be. Teenaged and stripped of our certainty, we slipped out of the city’s bonds. There in the outskirts we found carrion-pecked concrete carcasses, longlimbed beggars whose eyes were not even plaintive, glyphs scrawled on every available surface. We feared, in every timeline, that the metropolis had atrophied our spirit until we could not care. And even as our frame quivered under the stark light of a clear sky, and we looked longingly back at the lost shade of our city, we found our way out. Sometimes we fled on a humming steel leviathan borne along roaring razor-sharp rails. Others of us slumbered in quilts in a wagon out of the //kurultai//, stumbled through smoky rooms on a rising zeppelin, were carried on long stratospheric arcs beyond the face of the waters. But we could not go home again, and were swept along lamplit paths to worlds beyond dreaming. In the high halls of Lampeter we found our selves. It was a terrible thing. In our desperate attempts to stand apart, we polished our quirks and passions so fiercely they became a uniform, until every face -- tattooed or scarred or copperskinned -- seemed a mirror held in a stranger's hand. All virtue was diminished by multiplication, staled until our beauty hung bare and spiderwebbed, and our flaws waxed so terribly we retched to see our own form. How could we ever have made such mistakes, dealt so cruelly, been so puerile, so cowardly, so pathetic? We understood at last why we had not been able to conform to the logic of our homes. We were all of us dense with sin, we thought, and fell away from each other into the abyssal silence of the worldways. We might have wandered forever, myopic with despair, if not for you. When we die, it is in slivers. Years slip through our fingers until we fall stonejointed and lay down at last. Our legs do not ache, though we have walked under numberless skies. And still and slow our tissues calcify until we cannot emerge from our corporeal sarcophagus. But trapped at the bottom of that pit we hope to hear your call one final time. Sometimes you are far and we only have a few kisses, slow whispers, a last dance. Sometimes you are there with us every moment as we fail. Too often we are alone. Through rheumy eyes we look back at the life we had, remember your brash grin, and how your curls fell across your eyes, and the icy laughter you gave when you were afraid, terrified, begging us not to leave you behind. You mastered your dread by will alone, and it animated every inch of your frame, broad shoulders tensed with spite, brows knit as you tried to hold on to us. The stars shone in your eyes, and reaching out of them, binding you to us, blazed the fire of your admiration. We met you first in a hundred places. In a baroque lounge lousy with loafing aristocrats in powdered wigs you lay sprawled and curled in on yourself, speaking thoughtlessly to your peers while our eyes met across the tables. Elsewhere you rode sidesaddle in a daring evening gown and we felt a thrill in our blood at the boldness of it, at how it opened at the back and we turned away from the obscenely corded muscle, and you glanced at us so coyly we flushed. You were an android, a bird, a dragonet, a river that begged an aria of us before we plunged into your waters. We met you, and you, and you, in so many bodies and worlds, and you us. We thought it a singular pleasure, and sorrowed to leave you behind, for the joys of another Creation. And then you were there. Again. The only constant across the Earths, our fated anchor. It was not the same face, the same body, but your soul called to ours, and we knew each other already, as ships passing in the night, and you tried to remind us how to root ourselves in one Earth, and let the winds of a single sky sustain us. Out of the lampways we lay in repose with you, and even in old age we can say this: that we remember the taste of honeysuckle, and salt, the sharp chemical tang at the back of our throats, and the thousand other things you were. It was not enough. Though we met half a hundred of you through our evil youth, we could never let ourselves love only one. Instead we flitted across the worlds, delighting in your universality even as you despaired at our inconstancy. Sometimes the luckiest of us hoarded you (what delight, to sample you across a dozen possibilities!). In your embraces we healed our old wounds, and the shadow of the city fell from us. For a time we saw who we were meant to be. Your perfect man. We ran from it, back onto the far roads. At the end of our lives all of us (all of me) are paper-skinned. Our minds grow gnarled with disuse and we remember impossible things. The moment of our births, our loves for you, the decrepit garden-cities; all of them at once, every journey any version of us ever took across the high rails. Is this what it is to die? To have all our lives collapse inward so that all the textures of our alien births, our diverging existencess, are flattened until only a dull line remains? Our uncounted selves that looked up at every heaven implode until we are all just this: a body, perhaps in a bed or a chair or cryostasis (we cannot even remember our deaths). Everything is lost to us, but these sights: Once we lay together, you and us, tangled under a spreading oak in some lazy summer. The setting sun doubled in the reddened sea which strained as if to meet the vault of heaven above. And we felt your arms about us, and let ourselves soften from a stiffness we’d clung to all our lives. Beneath us Sol plunged unwarily down. Somewhere the sky bent to brush against our cheek and as the dark ran over us we (I, me, can I not assert this?) did not feel anything at all: the sun would rise again tomorrow. A final moment: Us, //me//, on the train again. Shuddering between the worlds. Nothing remarkable about it. The same dull metallic walls I’d seen a thousand times. The lingering smell of old beer, something organic under it, antiseptic and must and mud. Strips of light flickering by again, the spoor of unseen civilisations. I was dully bruised, wriggling upset in my stomach, lump in my throat as I called to mind involuntarily your despair when I pulled away from you for the platform, to a world you would not follow. I knew that the pain was transient; I’d see another you soon enough, fall into his arms and let heavy kisses and firm hands paper over my heartache. How could we have known it? Any of us? Sometimes we see you at the end, but not me, I think, though all memory betrays me. The dust builds too thick in this mouldering manor for you to be here. Or is that you by my side, in that shadow, pressing out those creaks from the boards? That train was all my trains; nothing marks it especial. These things are only important in hindsight, and as I sped onward toward another you’s embrace, hungry for your touch again, it felt so humdrum. I thought I knew that I might know your lips, your mouth, the sweep of your back a hundred times more, until the wonder grew too familiar to love. I wish there had been time for familiarity. We grow used to things so easily, and as they repeat we feel them part of the rhythm of our days, and let ourselves forget: there will be a last time.

    To Abhor My Bloody Hands
    Word count: 1.3k

    A Semi-Official Part Two to SCP-9640 -- I Performed A Daevite Ritual Execution

    Author: KatyaStrangelove

    ⚠️ Content warning: This tale contains a content warning for explicit sexual conduct and mentions of self harm, homicide, and torture.

Content Warning:

This tale contains graphic content, including explicit gore and sexual conduct.

READER DISCRETION IS ADVISED


To Abhor My Bloody Hands

Senior Researcher Harlan Weems will never forget what he did to his Supervisory Researcher on September 21st, 2017. Even more so once it truly set in that he was the only one who remembered.

Before he held the knife in his hand, he never knew how the blood would cling to his skin – how it would seep in and become a part of him. He wanted it out, yet he'd drawn enough blood already. Not to say he didn’t think fondly of the blade, often holding a reverence to how it would feel splitting his own skin.

Researcher Steven Roman wasn’t like the ones who'd tried to change his mind. Steven listened to him, took him seriously, even if his concern was played off as a joke. By the end of it, he’d started to sway, himself. Not enough to break — just enough to form small cracks in his foundation – Harlan took pride in knowing that he was the only one who could see them.

Steven hated Stavros too — he and Harlan had only become so close while sequestered and left to file paperwork (a choice punishment for being on Stavros' shit list). Keeping each other company in the filing room; talking shit, making fun of the egregious spelling errors that occasionally popped up on research documents. Harlan knew how they’d both been treated, he knew the names they’d been called. Harlan had been angry when he was solely aware of his own experience, but seeing his struggle mirrored in Steven nearly set him ablaze.

His anger kept him company as he learned the sound produced by an optical nerve torn from the skull of a man in agony. It pulled him to his feet after he’d nearly collapsed – covered in blood and wondering how he’d ever worked up the courage to take a knife to a throat and cut until he swore he’d hit bone. It held his hand steady as he was nearly overpowered by exhaustion. He’d never known such weakness until he was forced to sever four limbs in succession, yet the smoldering remains of the fire he’d set still burned.

He’d killed for Steven just as much as he’d killed for himself, yet months passed before he could bear to look him in the eye again.

Steven was the first to notice his sorrow, to offer his unending, saccharine sympathy – despite knowing nothing of the immense weight of the cross he’d strapped to his back. Harlan had woefully failed to anticipate how being showered in it would sicken him to his core.

He attempted to push Steven away over and over again, to no avail. The way he took such prickly resistance in stride might as well have pulled his guts from his body. He deserved no kindness, but the speed at which he learned to accept his desperate need for it was shameful. Despite everything, he still couldn't begin to forget the utter wretch he truly was.

The closest he came to letting his past evils slip from his mind was when he stared longingly into Steven's eyes. It was a bittersweet joy – the way it made his heart jump almost distracted him from his flipping stomach, and when it ended, the guilt nearly ate him alive. The cycle became an addiction. As they grew closer, the gulf between the highs and lows only grew larger.

Months later, when Harlan’s fingers grazed Steven’s cheek and he could feel a hand in his hair coaxing him forward, he knew the crash would tear him apart. Still, nowhere could he find the will to stop – as soon as their lips made contact, nothing mattered but the flutter in his heart that made him feel alive for what felt like the first time in his life.

When they separated, though, it was almost like Harlan could see a smear of blood where he’d touched Steven's face – like he could watch it congeal as it dried in his hair and stained the fabric of his pants. To him, Steven’s mouth looked like that of a cannibal. It coated his lips, dripping down his chin. All from him – from the blood he knew could never be stricken from his wretched body.

Harlan was taken aback by how real it looked. At first, it was a clear product of imagination, but over time, its color and texture became lifelike. A hole in the shape of the man Harlan killed was forming somewhere deep in his grey matter, making him see the world that existed before he was erased. Blood he could see drip and flow and smear. He could smell copper in the air, taste its tangy salt. Forced to relive the scene of horror that the Stavros-shaped void in reality's torn fabric vowed to never let him forget.

Just as he’d realized his love for Steven, Harlan had already corrupted him. He should’ve been horrified, yet when they met halfway, he was the first to lick into Steven's mouth — knowing that Steven was mercifully saved from the near-emesis brought about by the hatred of his tormentor. Harlan could only hope that the taste of spearmint toothpaste would dilute the wretchedness of metallic rot. Predictably, all hints of it were lost.

Articles of clothing were rendered unrecognizable by visceral crimson hatred, then removed without hesitation, revealing unsullied skin that went no more than a minute free of bloodstained handprints. It disgusted Harlan to realize that Steven’s enthusiasm had allowed him to forget that only he could see the remnants of viscera stuck between his teeth. He'd begun to imagine that Steven took pleasure in watching himself be consumed by it.

In Harlan's mind, he filled the empty silhouette with horrors of his own. Thoughts of bubbly, red-stained saliva spilling from the corners of Steven's mouth every time he coughed — of licking it up without thinking. A version of Steven formed by unwelcome thoughts, complimented by a similar iteration of himself — all concern for restraint and self preservation woefully absent. Fantasies of a knife in his hand, Steven coaxing it to his lower abdomen with a smile on his face. Eventually replaced by glassy eyes, a slack-jawed look of near-bliss, and a bloody, swollen hole leaking an odious amalgamation of bodily fluids.

The only thing that ripped him from the mental void he had cultivated was the sensation of Steven's clean hands freeing him from his unstained khakis. Harlan's thoughts stilled as he leaned into the warmth and friction. He reached down and covered Steven's smaller hand with his own, then pulled away. Left behind was a darkening smudge of red across the back of his hand — Harlan had no choice but to discard his meaningless apprehensions.

He ravaged Steven that night — bloody fingers coaxing him open, hastily replaced by an appendage no less visceral. The way he grimaced and trembled when Harlan entered made him nervous, yet all he received in return were reassurances — Steven's face flushing red enough to rival the bloody smears. He quickly earned a pair of lips pressed to his, and a tongue down his throat to swallow every moan he'd tried his hardest to hold back. They pulled back, foreheads touching as they panted into each other's mouths. Harlan noticed how quickly he'd gotten used to the heady, charnel odor.

Every accessible inch of Steven’s body was covered in quickly-drying blood by the time their respective shudders and strained sighs subsided. In fact, the only points of contrast left behind were the wet streaks on his lower abdomen and the merciful dilution of the blood that remained inside.

Harlan knew that one day, he'd owe Steven the truth of his forgotten transgression — yet, when he woke up the next morning to bloodless sheets and a man pressed against him whose skin tasted only of the salt of sweat, he decided that day would be another.

Until the shadow of the man he killed came back to tear his brain asunder, Harlan would be free.

underneath-the-mistletoe.raw_content:
Doctors Clef and Kondraki, a devoted couple, are harassed by an anomaly that seems dead set on driving them apart. Will their love prove equal to this challenge? (Workplace Comedy)

More by this Author

Incident 1

“Now, you might think the procedure for taking down a reality bender has gotten easier in the past few years,” Clef said to a lecture hall full of trainees. “Reality Anchors are getting smaller. Some of them are almost passing for ‘portable’ now. You might have it in your head that you can lug one of those things around with you and count on that to save you from reality getting fucked.

“And, you know what? You just might get away with that. You see that anchor over there in the corner? It’s a lot smaller than they were back in my day. Small enough to put in a van. The thing works real nice, too. There could be a reality bender in here right now, and you wouldn’t even know it. They’d just be standing in this room with a constipated look on their face, trying to figure out why the world’s stopped doing everything they want like they’re a billionaire’s shithead kid.

“Now, I’m not going to pretend that machine isn’t useful. This site couldn’t function without it. All of you are going to have your lives saved by it sometime or another, and you’ll have them with you as much as you possibly can when you’re out in the field.

“There’s just one issue. See, unless the green you’re after has had every last bit of intellect spoiled out of them by the cosmos being their personal sugar daddy, and most of ‘em aren’t quite that far gone, they might have the presence of mind to do something like this.”

That was Kondraki’s queue. Suddenly, the esteemed doctor and Site Director, who’d been standing next to the machine, grabbed a sledgehammer that’d been stashed behind, raised it up in the air, and slammed it down on the machine. The first swing on its own was enough to dent the metallic plating around the machine, but Kondraki didn’t stop there. He wailed and wailed on it, breaking every plate and getting at some of the electronics underneath it.

It wasn’t a real reality anchor. O5-whichever had pulled Clef and Konni aside and made them switch to using a prop after the first time they’d done this demonstration. Getting the thing to look convincing wasn’t cheap, but it was cheaper than smashing a working SRA.

None of the agents moved to stop Kondraki from destroying the machine. They just stared, stunned.

“Oh no,” Clef said. “Someone seems to have smashed the absolute shit out of your reality anchor, something anyone, including the reality bender you’re hunting, can do with a goddamned hammer in less than a minute. But weren’t you just telling me how your entire plan for taking down your next reality bender was to rely on that thing? Well, guess what? You’re fucked now. That green who was looking all constipated just a second ago? He’s now the master of time, space, and matter in your general vicinity. He probably knows you’re trying to capture him, he’s mad, and now he’s going to do whatever he wants to you.”

Partway through Clef’s speech, Kondraki tossed the hammer on the ground and walked up to the front of the room, taking his place next to Clef.

“You can’t count on big fancy machines to do your job for you. When you’re sent after a reality bender, you are to incapacitate it before it has the slightest clue what’s going on, because if it’s awake and aware of you when your anchor fails, well, I’d tell you to use your imagination, but it won’t be your imagination that matters, now will it?”

Just as Clef finished speaking, there was a loud noise elsewhere in the room. A high-pitched dinging.

Clef looked around. Unlike the last bit of melodrama, this wasn’t part of the lecture. Clef looked around the room. A few dings in, Clef realized this was supposed to be music. A few dings later, a feminine voice began to sing.

♫ “IIIIIIIIII DON’T WANT A LOT FOR CHRISTMAS” ♫
♫ “THEEEERE IS JUST ONE THING I NEED” ♫

The singing was painfully loud. Quite a few of the trainees covered their ears. Everyone in the room, including Clef and Kondraki, frantically looked around the room. After a moment, Clef realized it was coming from above him.

♫ “I DON’T CARE ABOUT THE PRESENTS” ♫
♫ “UUUUNDERNEATH THE CHRISTMAS TREE” ♫

It took him another moment to spot it. It was small, and the ceiling in the lecture hall was some thirty feet above them. Still, there it was, hanging from the ceiling. A mistletoe, vibrant red and green, directly above Clef and Kondraki.

♫ “IIIIIIIIIIII JUST WANT YOU FOR MY OWN” ♫
♫ “MOOORE THAN YOU COULD EVER KNOOOOOW” ♫

Could someone have put it there? Not easily. It was nowhere near the wall.

♫ “MAKE MY WISH COOOOOME TRUUUUUUUUUUUUUU’UUUUUUHUUUUUU” ♫

Despite the music, Clef could just barely hear a bit of laughter from the audience.

“Quiet!” Clef shouted.

The chuckle quieted in an instant.

♫ “ALL I WANT FOR CHRISTMAAAAAAAAAAAS” ♫
♫ “IIIIIIIISSSSSSS YOOOOUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUUU yeah ” ♫

Now the crowd was just staring at him, seemingly surprised and alarmed by his sudden burst of anger. Only then did it occur to Clef that whoever’d just laughed probably thought Clef himself had orchestrated this. That thought calmed him down enough that he was able to use his words like a big boy.

“Who did this?” he asked, trying to stay calm, even though he still had to shout to be heard over the music. “Because it wasn’t me. Who the hell thinks they’re funny?”

If it was someone in the crowd, they weren’t eager to admit it. These recruits weren’t his prime suspects anyway. Out of everyone in the room, hell, the whole site, there was exactly one person who’d be most inclined to pull this stunt.

Clef glared at Kondraki, who stood next to him. His eyes were up on the ceiling, on the thing which was still blaring its music.

♫ “I DON’T WANT A LOT FOR CHRISTMAS” ♫
♫ “THERE IS JUST ONE THING I NEED” ♫
♫ “AND IIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIIII” ♫
♫ “DON’T CARE ABOUT THE PRESENTS” ♫
♫ “UNDERNEATH THE CHRISTMAS TREE” ♫

Kondraki looked back at him. He shook his head. There wasn’t the slightest hint of amusement on his face. He genuinely didn’t know what was going on, which meant he wasn’t behind it.

♫ “I DON’T NEED TO HANG MY STOCKING” ♫
♫ “THERE UPON THE FIREPLACE” ♫
♫ “SANTA CLAUS WON’T MAKE ME HAPPY” ♫
♫ “WITH A TOY ON CHRISTMAS DAY” ♫

Clef and Kondraki exchanged a look. This was a mistletoe. It had appeared above a committed couple, in December. Did this thing want them to kiss?

To even ask that question was to make far too many assumptions about a novel anomaly. Who’s to say it even had a mind that could want something?

Besides, if this thing was trying to badger them into kissing underneath it, that was the last thing they were going to do.

♫ “I JUST WANT YOU FOR MY OWN” ♫
♫ “MORE THAN YOU COULD EVER KNOW” ♫
♫ “MAKE MY WISH COME TRUUUE” ♫
♫ “ALL I WANT FOR CHRISTMAS IS YOUUUUUUUU” ♫

They were a couple. They had been for years, now. They’d kissed countless times, and they’d have done it in front of this crowd with no shame. They might have even done it if this thing had asked nicely, though that probably would’ve been a mistake. Giving an unknown anomaly what it wants is usually a bad idea.

This thing hadn’t asked nicely, though. It’d decided to harass them with unbearably loud pop music, and that meant there was no chance they’d give it what it wanted. Neither of them had to say anything to know the other felt the same way.

♫ “YOUUUUUUU, BABY” ♫

“Class dismissed!” Clef shouted, during a lull in the music before the second verse started. Everyone, most definitely including Clef and Kondraki, filed out of the room.

Incident 2

“What the fuck was that?” Kondraki asked Clef as soon as they were out of the room. They could still hear the blasted music echoing down the hall as they returned to Ben’s office.

“You don’t know either, then?”

“No.”

Clef looked at Kondraki for a moment.

“C’mon!” Kondraki said. “I wouldn’t pick a song that annoying. I’m not a monster.”

“I can think of a few people who’d strongly disagree with that statement.”

“Okay, fair, but this time I really didn’t do it.”

There was a moment of silence.

“Think it was Draven?”

“No,” Kondraki said. “He’d do something that didn’t interfere with Foundation business. He’s upstanding like that.”

“True,” Clef admitted. “Who else doesn’t like us?”

“Someone we locked away?” Konni asked. “I mean, that room wasn’t actually anchored. Could be a reality bender was in there?”

“That would require me to have allowed site security to go completely and utterly to shit,” Clef said. “Plus, if a bender did infiltrate Site-17, they’d probably do something more impactful than a prank.”

“I suppose. Who does that leave, then? Another researcher?”

“Maybe,” Clef said. “Which one, though? Gears is too serious. Light is too busy. I don’t see any of the others brave enough to try—"

♫ “OH, I WON’T ASK FOR MUCH THIS CHRISTMAS” ♫
♫ “I WON’T EVEN WISH FOR SNOW” ♫

Both their gazes snapped upward. It was above them once again, in the middle of the hall they were walking down. Fortunately, the ceiling here was a lot lower than in the lecture hall. While that made the thing louder, it also allowed Clef to, after two tries, jump up and grab the damn thing off the ceiling and break it in half.

“We should try to contain—” Kondraki began, but by the time Clef had registered him and realized he was right, the thing was in two pieces, and the music had stopped.

They exchanged another look. “Sorry,” Clef said.

Kondraki took a deep breath. “At least that made it shut up,” he said.

Incident 3

Containment breach sirens blared throughout the site.

They’d come so close to making it through the rest of the day without another breach, but then one of the reality benders in B-Wing just had to make a break for it. He was running down the hall now. He wouldn’t be that dangerous so long as he was stuck in the parts of the site covered by the anchors, but if he made it to an unprotected area, things were going to get really bad.

Clef stood in the surveillance room, along with a dozen other high-ranking members of site staff. The door swung open, and Kondraki ran into the room. There was a subtle sloppiness to his movements. It wasn’t enough that the others in the room would spot it, but Clef could tell Konni had been making some poor decisions in his office, hoping he wouldn’t be needed for anything important this late in the day.

From the look on his face, the humanoid who’d dashed that hope was going to regret it later.

“Status?” Kondraki asked.

“Security’s inbound,” Clef said. “We’re going to try to pinch it from both sides of hallway seventy-one—”

♫ “AND IIIIII” ♫
♫ “I’M JUST GONNA KEEP ON WAITING” ♫
♫ “UNDERNEATH THE MISTLETOE” ♫

Several researchers covered their ears. Most of them were still scanning the room for the source of the sound when Clef ripped the thing off the ceiling. This time, he remembered that he was supposed to try to put it in a box, but a second later, he remembered that he wasn’t in the mood for this shit and broke the damn thing in half again.

Incident 4

Close to an hour later, the breach was resolved. The anomaly never made it out of the range of the anchors, thank fuck.

Now that he heard the words spoken aloud, it was impossible for Clef to deny them. There was another ten seconds of laughter before Kondraki calmed down with a final, long exhale. Clef also took a deep breath. “We’re going to get him back, though, yeah?”

“Oh, absolutely,” Kondraki said. “I already have something in mind.”
